## Problem Kuznetsov Integrals 18-23

## Material from PlusPi
informal_statement:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the parametric equations.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\left(t^{2}-2\right) \sin t+2 t \cos t \\
y=\left(2-t^{2}\right) \cos t+2 t \sin t
\end{array}\right. \\
& 0 \leq t \leq 2 \pi
\end{aligned}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- ## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the parametric equations.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\left(t^{2}-2\right) \sin t+2 t \cos t \\
y=\left(2-t^{2}\right) \cos t+2 t \sin t
\end{array}\right. \\
& 0 \leq t \leq 2 \pi
\end{aligned}
$$ -/
theorem calculus_152695 (f : ℝ → ℝ × ℝ)
  (hf : f = λ t => ((t^2 - 2)*sin t + 2*t*cos t, (2 - t^2)*cos t + 2*t*sin t)) :
  ∫ t in (0)..(2*π), Real.sqrt ((deriv f t).1^2 + (deriv f t).2^2) = 8*π^3 / 3 := by

soln_description:
Proof: Without loss of generality, let $a \geqslant b \geqslant c$. Then, by the two-variable mean inequality and the boundedness of the sine function, we get
$$\begin{array}{l}
\min \left\{\sqrt{a^{4}+b^{4}}, \sqrt{b^{4}+c^{4}}, \sqrt{c^{4}+a^{4}}\right\} \geqslant \sqrt{b^{4}+c^{4}} \\
\geqslant \sqrt{2 b^{2} c^{2}} \geqslant 2 \sqrt{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2} b c \sin A=2 \sqrt{2} \Delta .
\end{array}$$

Therefore, $\min \left\{\sqrt{a^{4}+b^{4}}, \sqrt{b^{4}+c^{4}}, \sqrt{c^{4}+a^{4}}\right\} \geqslant 2 \sqrt{2} \Delta$.
informal_statement: Example 1 Let the three sides of $\triangle A B C$ be $a, b, c$, and the area be $\Delta$, then $\min \left\{\sqrt{a^{4}+b^{4}}, \sqrt{b^{4}+c^{4}}, \sqrt{c^{4}+a^{4}}\right\} \geqslant 2 \sqrt{2} \Delta$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 1 Let the three sides of $\triangle A B C$ be $a, b, c$, and the area be $\Delta$, then $\min \left\{\sqrt{a^{4}+b^{4}}, \sqrt{b^{4}+c^{4}}, \sqrt{c^{4}+a^{4}}\right\} \geqslant 2 \sqrt{2} \Delta$. -/
theorem inequalities_603218 (a b c : ℝ) (h₀ : 0 < a) (h₁ : 0 < b) (h₂ : 0 < c)
  (h₃ : a + b > c) (h₄ : a + c > b) (h₅ : b + c > a) (Δ : ℝ)
  (hΔ : Δ = (1/2) * a * b * sin (arccos ((a^2 + b^2 - c^2)/(2*a*b)))) :
  min (min (Real.sqrt (a^4 + b^4)) (Real.sqrt (b^4 + c^4))) (Real.sqrt (c^4 + a^4)) ≥
  2 * Real.sqrt 2 * Δ :=

soln_description:
(a) Let

$$
L_{1}:=\{2 k: k>0\}, \quad E_{1}:=\{0\} \cup\{4 k+1: k \geq 0\}, \text { and } G_{1}:=\{4 k+3: k \geq 0\}
$$

We will show that $L_{1}=L, E_{1}=E$, and $G_{1}=G$. It suffices to verify that $L_{1} \subseteq E, E_{1} \subseteq E$, and $G_{1} \subseteq G$ because $L_{1}, E_{1}$, and $G_{1}$ are mutually disjoint and $L_{1} \cup E_{1} \cup G_{1}=\mathbb{N}_{0}$.

Firstly, if $k>0$, then $f(2 k)-f(2 k+1)=-k<0$ and therefore $L_{1} \subseteq L$.

Secondly, $f(0)=0$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(4 k+1)=2 k+2 f(2 k)=2 k+4 f(k) \\
& f(4 k+2)=2 f(2 k+1)=2(k+2 f(k))=2 k+4 f(k)
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $k \geq 0$. Thus, $E_{1} \subseteq E$.

Lastly, in order to prove $G_{1} \subset G$, we claim that $f(n+1)-f(n) \leq n$ for all $n$. (In fact, one can prove a stronger inequality: $f(n+1)-f(n) \leq n / 2$.) This is clearly true for even $n$ from the definition since for $n=2 t$,

$$
f(2 t+1)-f(2 t)=t \leq n \text {. }
$$

If $n=2 t+1$ is odd, then (assuming inductively that the result holds for all nonnegative $m<n$ ), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(n+1)-f(n) & =f(2 t+2)-f(2 t+1)=2 f(t+1)-t-2 f(t) \\
& =2(f(t+1)-f(t))-t \leq 2 t-t=t<n .
\end{aligned}
$$

For all $k \geq 0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(4 k+4)-f(4 k+3)=f(2(2 k+2))-f(2(2 k+1)+1) \\
& =4 f(k+1)-(2 k+1+2 f(2 k+1))=4 f(k+1)-(2 k+1+2 k+4 f(k)) \\
& =4(f(k+1)-f(k))-(4 k+1) \leq 4 k-(4 k+1)<0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

This proves $G_{1} \subseteq G$.

(b) Note that $a_{0}=a_{1}=f(1)=0$. Let $k \geq 2$ and let $N_{k}=\left\{0,1,2, \ldots, 2^{k}\right\}$. First we claim that the maximum $a_{k}$ occurs at the largest number in $G \cap N_{k}$, that is, $a_{k}=f\left(2^{k}-1\right)$. We use mathematical induction on $k$ to prove the claim. Note that $a_{2}=f(3)=f\left(2^{2}-1\right)$.

Now let $k \geq 3$. For every even number $2 t$ with $2^{k-1}+1<2 t \leq 2^{k}$,

$$
f(2 t)=2 f(t) \leq 2 a_{k-1}=2 f\left(2^{k-1}-1\right)
$$

by induction hypothesis. For every odd number $2 t+1$ with $2^{k-1}+1 \leq 2 t+1<2^{k}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(2 t+1) & =t+2 f(t) \leq 2^{k-1}-1+2 f(t) \\
& \leq 2^{k-1}-1+2 a_{k-1}=2^{k-1}-1+2 f\left(2^{k-1}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

again by induction hypothesis. Combining $(\dagger),(\ddagger)$ and

$$
f\left(2^{k}-1\right)=f\left(2\left(2^{k-1}-1\right)+1\right)=2^{k-1}-1+2 f\left(2^{k-1}-1\right)
$$

we may conclude that $a_{k}=f\left(2^{k}-1\right)$ as desired.

Furthermore, we obtain

$$
a_{k}=2 a_{k-1}+2^{k-1}-1
$$

for all $k \geq 3$. Note that this recursive formula for $a_{k}$ also holds for $k \geq 0,1$ and 2 . Unwinding this recursive formula, we finally get

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{k} & =2 a_{k-1}+2^{k-1}-1=2\left(2 a_{k-2}+2^{k-2}-1\right)+2^{k-1}-1 \\
& =2^{2} a_{k-2}+2 \cdot 2^{k-1}-2-1=2^{2}\left(2 a_{k-3}+2^{k-3}-1\right)+2 \cdot 2^{k-1}-2-1 \\
& =2^{3} a_{k-3}+3 \cdot 2^{k-1}-2^{2}-2-1 \\
& \vdots \\
& =2^{k} a_{0}+k 2^{k-1}-2^{k-1}-2^{k-2}-\ldots-2-1 \\
& =k 2^{k-1}-2^{k}+1 \quad \text { for all } k \geq 0 .
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement:
Consider the function $f: \mathbb{N}_{0} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}_{0}$, where $\mathbb{N}_{0}$ is the set of all non-negative integers, defined by the following conditions :
(i) $f(0)=0$,
(ii) $f(2 n)=2 f(n)$ and
(iii) $f(2 n+1)=n+2 f(n)$ for all $n \geq 0$.

(a) Determine the three sets $L:=\{n \mid f(n)f(n+1)\}$.

(b) For each $k \geq 0$, find a formula for $a_{k}:=\max \left\{f(n): 0 \leq n \leq 2^{k}\right\}$ in terms of $k$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Consider the function $f: \mathbb{N}_{0} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}_{0}$, where $\mathbb{N}_{0}$ is the set of all non-negative integers, defined by the following conditions :
(i) $f(0)=0$,
(ii) $f(2 n)=2 f(n)$ and
(iii) $f(2 n+1)=n+2 f(n)$ for all $n \geq 0$.

(a) Determine the three sets $L:=\{n \mid f(n)f(n+1)\}$.

(b) For each $k \geq 0$, find a formula for $a_{k}:=\max \left\{f(n): 0 \leq n \leq 2^{k}\right\}$ in terms of $k$. -/
theorem number_theory_260678 (f : ℕ → ℕ)
    (h₀ : f 0 = 0)
    (h₁ : ∀ n, f (2 * n) = 2 * f n)
    (h₂ : ∀ n, f (2 * n + 1) = n + 2 * f n) :
    {n | f n * f (n + 1) = 0} = {0, 1} ∧
    {n | f n * f (n + 1) = 1} = {1, 2} ∧
    {n | f n * f (n + 1) = 2} = {2, 3} ∧
    ∀ k, IsGreatest {x | ∃ n, x = f n ∧ n ≤ 2 ^ k} (k * 2 ^ (k - 1) - 2 ^ k + 1) := by

informal_statement: For all real numbers $x, y$ satisfying $|x|+|y|\leqslant 1$, the inequality $|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}|+|y-1|+|2y-x-3|\leqslant a$ always holds, then the minimum value of the real number $a$ is ___          ___ .
informal_proof:
We aim to prove a biconditional statement: for all real numbers $x, y$ such that $|x|+|y| \le 1$, the inequality $|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}|+|y-1|+|2y-x-3|\leqslant a$ holds if and only if $a \ge \frac{23}{2}$. We will establish both implications.

First, assume that the inequality holds for all real numbers $x, y$ satisfying $|x|+|y| \le 1$. To determine a lower bound for $a$, we can evaluate the expression $|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}|+|y-1|+|2y-x-3|$ at a specific point $(x, y)$ within the domain $|x|+|y| \le 1$. Let us choose $x=0$ and $y=-1$. We verify that this point satisfies the condition: $|0|+|-1|=0+1=1$, which is indeed less than or equal to 1.

Now, we substitute $x=0$ and $y=-1$ into the expression:
$$|2(0)-3(-1)+\frac{3}{2}|+|(-1)-1|+|2(-1)-0-3| = |0+3+\frac{3}{2}|+|-2|+|-2-3| = |\frac{9}{2}|+2+|-5| = \frac{9}{2}+2+5 = \frac{9}{2}+7 = \frac{23}{2}.$$
Since the inequality $|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}|+|y-1|+|2y-x-3|\leqslant a$ is assumed to hold for all such $x, y$, it must hold for $(0, -1)$. Thus, we have $\frac{23}{2} \le a$.

Next, assume that $a \ge \frac{23}{2}$. We need to prove that for any real numbers $x, y$ such that $|x|+|y| \le 1$, the inequality $|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}|+|y-1|+|2y-x-3|\leqslant a$ is satisfied.

Consider the expression $E(x, y) = |2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}|+|y-1|+|2y-x-3|$.
We analyze the terms $|y-1|$ and $|2y-x-3|$ within the domain $|x|+|y| \le 1$.
Since $|y| \le |x|+|y| \le 1$, we have $-1 \le y \le 1$. This implies $y-1 \le 0$, so $|y-1| = -(y-1) = 1-y$.
Also, from $|x| \le 1$, we have $-x \le 1$. Combining this with $y \le 1$, we get $2y-x-3 \le 2(1) + 1 - 3 = 0$. Thus, $|2y-x-3| = -(2y-x-3) = x-2y+3$.

The inequality we need to prove can be rewritten as:
$$|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}| + (1-y) + (x-2y+3) \le a$$
$$|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}| + x - 3y + 4 \le a$$

To show this inequality holds for all $(x, y)$ with $|x|+|y| \le 1$, we can consider the maximum value of the expression $E(x, y)$ over this domain. The domain $|x|+|y| \le 1$ defines a square in the $xy$-plane with vertices at $(1,0), (-1,0), (0,1), (0,-1)$. The function $E(x,y)$, being a sum of absolute values of linear functions, is convex. The maximum of a convex function over a compact convex set is attained at one of the extreme points (vertices).

Let's evaluate $E(x, y)$ at these vertices:
\begin{itemize}
    \item At $(1,0)$: $E(1,0) = |2(1)-3(0)+\frac{3}{2}|+|0-1|+|2(0)-1-3| = |\frac{7}{2}|+|-1|+|-4| = \frac{7}{2}+1+4 = \frac{17}{2}$.
    \item At $(-1,0)$: $E(-1,0) = |2(-1)-3(0)+\frac{3}{2}|+|0-1|+|2(0)-(-1)-3| = |-\frac{1}{2}|+|-1|+|1-3| = \frac{1}{2}+1+2 = \frac{7}{2}$.
    \item At $(0,1)$: $E(0,1) = |2(0)-3(1)+\frac{3}{2}|+|1-1|+|2(1)-0-3| = |-\frac{3}{2}|+|0|+|-1| = \frac{3}{2}+0+1 = \frac{5}{2}$.
    \item At $(0,-1)$: $E(0,-1) = |2(0)-3(-1)+\frac{3}{2}|+|-1-1|+|2(-1)-0-3| = |\frac{9}{2}|+|-2|+|-5| = \frac{9}{2}+2+5 = \frac{23}{2}$.
\end{itemize}
The maximum value of $E(x, y)$ on the domain $|x|+|y| \le 1$ is $\frac{23}{2}$, achieved at $(0, -1)$.

Since we assumed $a \ge \frac{23}{2}$, and the maximum value of the expression is $\frac{23}{2}$, it follows that for all $x, y$ satisfying $|x|+|y| \le 1$, we have $E(x, y) \le \frac{23}{2} \le a$. Thus, the inequality $|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}|+|y-1|+|2y-x-3|\leqslant a$ holds.

Both implications have been proven, establishing the biconditional statement.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- For all real numbers $x, y$ satisfying $|x|+|y|\leqslant 1$, the inequality $|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}|+|y-1|+|2y-x-3|\leqslant a$ always holds, then the minimum value of the real number $a$ is ___          ___. -/
/- For all real numbers $x, y$ satisfying $|x|+|y|\leqslant 1$, the inequality $|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}|+|y-1|+|2y-x-3|\leqslant a$ always holds, then the minimum value of the real number $a$ is ___          ___ . -/
theorem inequalities_11830 (a : ℝ) :
    (∀ x y : ℝ, |x| + |y| ≤ 1 → |2 * x - 3 * y + 3 / 2| + |y - 1| + |2 * y - x - 3| ≤ a) ↔
    a ≥ 23 / 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- For all real numbers $x, y$ satisfying $|x|+|y|\leqslant 1$, the inequality $|2x-3y+\frac{3}{2}|+|y-1|+|2y-x-3|\leqslant a$ always holds, then the minimum value of the real number $a$ is ___          ___. -/
theorem inequalities_11830 (a : ℝ) :
    (∀ x y : ℝ, |x| + |y| ≤ 1 → |2 * x - 3 * y + 3 / 2| + |y - 1| + |2 * y - x - 3| ≤ a) ↔
    a ≥ 23 / 2 := by
  constructor
  · -- Assume the inequality holds for all x, y with |x| + |y| ≤ 1, prove a ≥ 23/2
    intro h
    have h1 := h 0 (-1) (by
      norm_num [abs_le]
    )
    norm_num [abs] at h1 ⊢
    linarith
  · -- Assume a ≥ 23/2, prove the inequality for all x,y with |x| + |y| ≤ 1
    intro ha x y h
    have h1 : |x| + |y| ≤ 1 := h
    cases' abs_cases x with hx hx <;> cases' abs_cases y with hy hy <;> 
      cases' abs_cases (2 * x - 3 * y + 3 / 2) with h1 h1 <;> 
        cases' abs_cases (y - 1) with h2 h2 <;> 
          cases' abs_cases (2 * y - x - 3) with h3 h3 <;> 
            all_goals 
              linarith

informal_statement:
Show that 
\[ \frac{(b+c)(a^4-b^2c^2)}{ab+2bc+ca}+\frac{(c+a)(b^4-c^2a^2)}{bc+2ca+ab}+\frac{(a+b)(c^4-a^2b^2)}{ca+2ab+bc} \geq 0 \]
for all positive real numbers $a, \: b , \: c.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that 
\[ \frac{(b+c)(a^4-b^2c^2)}{ab+2bc+ca}+\frac{(c+a)(b^4-c^2a^2)}{bc+2ca+ab}+\frac{(a+b)(c^4-a^2b^2)}{ca+2ab+bc} \geq 0 \]
for all positive real numbers $a, \: b , \: c.$ -/
theorem inequalities_61839 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    (b + c) * (a ^ 4 - b ^ 2 * c ^ 2) / (a * b + 2 * b * c + c * a) +
    (c + a) * (b ^ 4 - c ^ 2 * a ^ 2) / (b * c + 2 * c * a + a * b) +
    (a + b) * (c ^ 4 - a ^ 2 * b ^ 2) / (c * a + 2 * a * b + b * c) ≥ 0 := by

soln_description: Proof: Without loss of generality, let this rational number be $b / a, a \geqslant 1,(a, b)=1$. If $(b / a)^{k}=c$ is an integer, then $c a^{k}=b^{k}$, so $a \mid b^{k}$. Since $(a, b)=1$, it follows from Theorem 6 that $a \mid b$, hence $1=(a, b)=a$. This proves the desired result.
informal_statement: Example 3 Let $k$ be a positive integer. If the $k$-th power of a rational number is an integer, then this rational number must be an integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 3 Let $k$ be a positive integer. If the $k$-th power of a rational number is an integer, then this rational number must be an integer. -/
theorem number_theory_5845 (k : ℕ) (hk : 0 < k) (a : ℚ) (h : ∃ n : ℤ, a ^ k = n) :
    ∃ m : ℤ, a = m := by

soln_description:
1. If $n$ is odd, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
3^{n}+n^{2}+2019 \equiv(-1)^{n}+n^{2}+3 \\
\equiv 3(\bmod 4),
\end{array}
$$

it cannot be a perfect square.
Therefore, $n$ is even.
Let $n=2 m\left(m \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$. Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
3^{n}+n^{2}+2019=3^{2 m}+4 m^{2}+2019>\left(3^{m}\right)^{2} \\
\Rightarrow 3^{2 m}+4 m^{2}+2019 \geqslant\left(3^{m}+1\right)^{2} \\
\Rightarrow 3^{m}-2 m^{2} \leqslant 1009 .
\end{array}
$$

When $m \geqslant 7$, use mathematical induction to prove:
$$
3^{m}>2 m^{2}+1009 \text {. }
$$

When $m=7$, the conclusion holds.
Assume the proposition holds for $m$, i.e.,
$$
3^{m}>2 m^{2}+1009 \text {. }
$$

When $m+1$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
3^{m+1}>3\left(2 m^{2}+1009\right)=6 m^{2}+3027 \\
>2(m+1)^{2}+1009 .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, the proposition holds for $m+1$.
Therefore, the inequality is proved.
Hence, $m \leqslant 6$.
When $m=1$,
$$
3^{2 m}+4 m^{2}+2019=2032,
$$

it is not a perfect square.
When $m=2$,
$$
3^{2 m}+4 m^{2}+2019=2116=46^{2} \text {, }
$$

satisfying the condition.
When $m=3$ or 6,
$$
3^{2 m}+4 m^{2}+2019 \equiv 3(\bmod 9),
$$

it is not a perfect square.
When $m=4$,
$$
3^{2 m}+4 m^{2}+2019 \equiv 6(\bmod 7),
$$

it is not a perfect square.
When $m=5$,
$$
3^{2 m}+4 m^{2}+2019 \equiv 3(\bmod 5),
$$

it is not a perfect square.
In summary, the only positive integer that satisfies the condition is $n=4$.
informal_statement:
1. Find all positive integers $n$, such that $3^{n}+n^{2}+2019$ is a perfect square.
（Zou Jin, contributed）
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Find all positive integers $n$, such that $3^{n}+n^{2}+2019$ is a perfect square.
（Zou Jin, contributed） -/
theorem number_theory_249413 (n : ℕ) :
    n > 0 ∧ ∃ m, m^2 = 3^n + n^2 + 2019 ↔ n = 4 := by

Answer: 13

informal_statement: 3. The polynomial $P(x)$ of the third degree, as well as its first, second, and third derivatives, take the value 1 at $x=-3$. Find $\mathrm{P}(0)$.
informal_proof:
Let $P(x)$ be a cubic polynomial. We can express $P(x)$ in its general form:
\[ P(x) = ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d \]
where $a, b, c, d$ are real coefficients.

We are given the following conditions:
1.  $P(-3) = 1$
2.  The first derivative of $P$ evaluated at $-3$ is $1$, i.e., $P'(-3) = 1$.
3.  The second derivative of $P$ evaluated at $-3$ is $1$, i.e., $P''(-3) = 1$.
4.  The third derivative of $P$ evaluated at $-3$ is $1$, i.e., $P'''(-3) = 1$.

First, we compute the derivatives of $P(x)$:
*   The first derivative is $P'(x) = 3ax^2 + 2bx + c$.
*   The second derivative is $P''(x) = 6ax + 2b$.
*   The third derivative is $P'''(x) = 6a$.

Now, we apply the given conditions by substituting $x = -3$ into these expressions:
1.  $P(-3) = a(-3)^3 + b(-3)^2 + c(-3) + d = -27a + 9b - 3c + d$.
    So, we have the equation: $-27a + 9b - 3c + d = 1$.

2.  $P'(-3) = 3a(-3)^2 + 2b(-3) + c = 3a(9) - 6b + c = 27a - 6b + c$.
    So, we have the equation: $27a - 6b + c = 1$.

3.  $P''(-3) = 6a(-3) + 2b = -18a + 2b$.
    So, we have the equation: $-18a + 2b = 1$.

4.  $P'''(-3) = 6a$.
    So, we have the equation: $6a = 1$.

We now have a system of four linear equations with four variables $a, b, c, d$:
(I)   $-27a + 9b - 3c + d = 1$
(II)  $27a - 6b + c = 1$
(III) $-18a + 2b = 1$
(IV)  $6a = 1$

We solve this system. From equation (IV), we get:
$a = \frac{1}{6}$

Substitute the value of $a$ into equation (III):
$-18\left(\frac{1}{6}\right) + 2b = 1$
$-3 + 2b = 1$
$2b = 4$
$b = 2$

Substitute the values of $a$ and $b$ into equation (II):
$27\left(\frac{1}{6}\right) - 6(2) + c = 1$
$\frac{27}{6} - 12 + c = 1$
$\frac{9}{2} - 12 + c = 1$
$c = 1 + 12 - \frac{9}{2}$
$c = 13 - \frac{9}{2}$
$c = \frac{26 - 9}{2} = \frac{17}{2}$

Substitute the values of $a, b, c$ into equation (I):
$-27\left(\frac{1}{6}\right) + 9(2) - 3\left(\frac{17}{2}\right) + d = 1$
$-\frac{27}{6} + 18 - \frac{51}{2} + d = 1$
$-\frac{9}{2} + 18 - \frac{51}{2} + d = 1$
$18 - \frac{60}{2} + d = 1$
$18 - 30 + d = 1$
$-12 + d = 1$
$d = 13$

We are asked to find $P(0)$. Using the general form of the polynomial:
$P(0) = a(0)^3 + b(0)^2 + c(0) + d = d$

Since we found that $d = 13$, we have $P(0) = 13$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. The polynomial $P(x)$ of the third degree, as well as its first, second, and third derivatives, take the value 1 at $x=-3$. Find $\mathrm{P}(0)$. -/
theorem algebra_211171 {P : ℝ → ℝ} (hP : ∃ a b c d : ℝ, P = fun x => a*x^3 + b*x^2 + c*x + d)
    (hP1 : P (-3) = 1) (hP2 : deriv P (-3) = 1) (hP3 : iteratedDeriv 2 P (-3) = 1)
    (hP4 : iteratedDeriv 3 P (-3) = 1) :
    P 0 = 13 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_211171 {P : ℝ → ℝ} (hP : ∃ a b c d : ℝ, P = fun x => a*x^3 + b*x^2 + c*x + d)
    (hP1 : P (-3) = 1) (hP2 : deriv P (-3) = 1) (hP3 : iteratedDeriv 2 P (-3) = 1)
    (hP4 : iteratedDeriv 3 P (-3) = 1) :
    P 0 = 13 := by
  rcases hP with ⟨a, b, c, d, hP'⟩
  have eq1 : P (-3) = a * (-3) ^ 3 + b * (-3) ^ 2 + c * (-3) + d := by 
    rw [hP']
    all_goals norm_num 
    all_goals ring 
  -- Express P(0)
  have eq5 : P 0 = d := by 
    rw [hP']
    norm_num
    all_goals ring 
  have eq6 : deriv P (-3) = 3 * a * (-3) ^ 2 + 2 * b * (-3) + c := by
    rw [hP']
    simp [deriv_pow, deriv_add, deriv_const, mul_comm c, mul_assoc]
    all_goals norm_num 
    all_goals ring_nf
    all_goals norm_num [mul_add, mul_assoc]
  -- Compute the second derivative 
  have eq8 : iteratedDeriv 2 P (-3) = 6 * a * (-3) + 2 * b := by
    have eq9 : iteratedDeriv 2 P (-3) = deriv (deriv P) (-3) := by 
      simp [iteratedDeriv_succ]
      <;> rfl 
    rw [eq9]
    have hP'_deriv : deriv P = fun x => 3 * a * x ^ 2 + 2 * b * x + c := by 
      funext x 
      rw [hP']
      simp [deriv_pow, deriv_add, deriv_const, mul_comm c, mul_assoc]
      all_goals ring_nf 
      all_goals norm_num [mul_add, mul_assoc]
      all_goals ring 
      all_goals norm_num
      all_goals ring 
    rw [hP'_deriv]
    simp [deriv_pow, deriv_add, deriv_const, mul_comm (2 * b), mul_assoc]
    all_goals norm_num 
    all_goals ring_nf 
    all_goals norm_num [mul_add, mul_assoc]
  -- Compute the third derivative
  have eq10 : iteratedDeriv 3 P (-3) = 6 * a := by 
    have eq11 : iteratedDeriv 3 P (-3) = deriv (iteratedDeriv 2 P) (-3) := by 
      simp [iteratedDeriv_succ]
      <;> rfl 
    rw [eq11]
    have hP'_deriv_2 : iteratedDeriv 2 P = fun x => 6 * a * x + 2 * b := by 
      funext x
      have eq17 : iteratedDeriv 2 P x = deriv (deriv P) x := by 
        simp [iteratedDeriv_succ]
        <;> rfl 
      have eq18 : deriv P = fun x => 3 * a * x ^ 2 + 2 * b * x + c := by 
        funext x 
        rw [hP']
        simp [deriv_pow, deriv_add, deriv_const, mul_comm c, mul_assoc]
        all_goals ring_nf 
        all_goals norm_num [mul_add, mul_assoc]
        all_goals ring 
      rw [eq17, eq18]
      simp [deriv_pow, deriv_add, deriv_const, mul_comm (2 * b), mul_assoc]
      all_goals ring_nf 
      all_goals norm_num [mul_add, mul_assoc]
      all_goals ring 
      all_goals norm_num 
    rw [hP'_deriv_2]
    simp [deriv_add, deriv_const, deriv_id', mul_comm (6 * a)]
    all_goals norm_num 
    all_goals ring_nf 
    all_goals norm_num [mul_add, mul_assoc]
  -- Now express the given conditions in terms of coefficients
  have eq6' : a * (-3) ^ 3 + b * (-3) ^ 2 + c * (-3) + d = 1 := by
    linarith [hP1, eq1]
  -- Second equation
  have eq7' : 3 * a * (-3) ^ 2 + 2 * b * (-3) + c = 1 := by 
    linarith [hP2, eq6]
  -- Third equation
  have eq8' : 6 * a * (-3) + 2 * b = 1 := by 
    linarith [hP3, eq8]
  -- Fourth equation 
  have eq9' : 6 * a = 1 := by 
    linarith [hP4, eq10]
  -- Solving the linear system
  have ha1 : a = 1 / 6 := by linarith
  have hb1 : b = 2 := by 
    rw [ha1] at eq8'
    linarith 
  have hc1 : c = 17 / 2 := by 
    rw [ha1, hb1] at eq7'
    linarith 
  have hd1 : d = 13 := by 
    rw [ha1, hb1, hc1] at eq6'
    linarith 
  -- Final computation
  rw [eq5]
  all_goals norm_num [hd1]
  all_goals linarith
  all_goals norm_num 
  all_goals linarith 
  all_goals norm_num
  all_goals linarith

informal_statement:
## 3. Prove the identity

$$
\frac{1}{\log _{5} x}+\frac{1}{\log _{5^{2}} x}+\frac{1}{\log _{5^{3}} x}+\ldots+\frac{1}{\log _{5^{10}} x}=\frac{55}{\log _{5} x}
$$
informal_proof:
We are given the identity to prove:
$$
\sum_{i \in \text{Finset.range } 10} \frac{1}{\log_{5^{i+1}} x} = \frac{55}{\log_5 x}
$$
for a real number $x$ satisfying $0 < x$ and $x \neq 1$. These conditions ensure that the logarithmic terms are well-defined and non-zero.

We first establish a simplification for the general term $\frac{1}{\log_{5^{k+1}} x}$ for any natural number $k$. Using the change-of-base formula for logarithms, $\log_a b = \frac{\log c}{\log a}$, we can write $\log_{5^{k+1}} x = \frac{\log x}{\log(5^{k+1})}$.
Applying the logarithm power rule, $\log(a^b) = b \log a$, we have $\log(5^{k+1}) = (k+1) \log 5$.
Substituting this, we get $\log_{5^{k+1}} x = \frac{\log x}{(k+1) \log 5}$.
Taking the reciprocal yields $\frac{1}{\log_{5^{k+1}} x} = \frac{(k+1) \log 5}{\log x}$.
This can be rewritten as $\frac{k+1}{\frac{\log x}{\log 5}}$, which simplifies to $\frac{k+1}{\log_5 x}$ by the change-of-base formula.

Now, we apply this simplified form to each term in the sum. The original sum is:
$$
\sum_{i \in \text{Finset.range } 10} \frac{1}{\log_{5^{i+1}} x}
$$
Using the derived identity for each term, where $i+1$ corresponds to $k+1$ in our general term simplification, we have:
$$
\sum_{i \in \text{Finset.range } 10} \frac{1}{\log_{5^{i+1}} x} = \sum_{i \in \text{Finset.range } 10} \frac{i+1}{\log_5 x}
$$
Since $\frac{1}{\log_5 x}$ is a constant with respect to the summation index $i$, we can factor it out of the sum:
$$
\sum_{i \in \text{Finset.range } 10} \frac{i+1}{\log_5 x} = \left(\sum_{i \in \text{Finset.range } 10} (i+1)\right) \cdot \frac{1}{\log_5 x}
$$
The sum $\sum_{i \in \text{Finset.range } 10} (i+1)$ is the sum of the integers from $1$ to $10$. This is an arithmetic series $1 + 2 + \ldots + 10$. The sum of the first $n$ positive integers is $\frac{n(n+1)}{2}$. For $n=10$, the sum is $\frac{10(10+1)}{2} = \frac{10 \times 11}{2} = 55$.

Substituting this result, the expression becomes:
$$
55 \cdot \frac{1}{\log_5 x} = \frac{55}{\log_5 x}
$$
This completes the proof of the identity.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- ## 3. Prove the identity

$$
\frac{1}{\log _{5} x}+\frac{1}{\log _{5^{2}} x}+\frac{1}{\log _{5^{3}} x}+\ldots+\frac{1}{\log _{5^{10}} x}=\frac{55}{\log _{5} x}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_251005 (x : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x ∧ x ≠ 1) :
    ∑ i ∈ Finset.range 10, (1 / logb (5 ^ (i + 1)) x) = 55 / logb 5 x := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem algebra_251005 (x : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x ∧ x ≠ 1) :
    ∑ i ∈ Finset.range 10, (1 / logb (5 ^ (i + 1)) x) = 55 / logb 5 x := by
  have hx1 : 0 < x := hx.1
  have hx2 : x ≠ 1 := hx.2
  have h : ∀ (k : ℕ), 1 / logb (5 ^ (k + 1)) x = (k + 1 : ℝ) / logb 5 x := by
    intro k
    have h1 : logb (5 ^ (k + 1)) x = log x / ((k + 1 : ℝ) * log (5 : ℝ)) := by
      have h2 : log (5 ^ (k + 1 : ℕ)) = (k + 1 : ℝ) * log (5 : ℝ) := by
        simp [log_pow]
      have h3 : logb (5 ^ (k + 1 : ℕ)) x = log x / log (5 ^ (k + 1 : ℕ)) := by 
        field_simp [logb]
      rw [h3, h2]
    have h4 : logb (5 : ℝ) x = log x / log (5 : ℝ) := by 
      field_simp [logb]
    rw [h1, h4]
    field_simp
    all_goals ring
  have h2 : ∑ i in Finset.range 10, (1 / logb (5 ^ (i + 1)) x) = ∑ i in Finset.range 10, ((i + 1 : ℝ) / logb 5 x) := by
    apply Finset.sum_congr
    · rfl
    intro i hi
    specialize h i
    simpa using h
  rw [h2]
  have h4 : ∑ i in Finset.range 10, ((i + 1 : ℝ) / logb 5 x) = (55 : ℝ) / logb 5 x := by
    have h5 : ∑ i in Finset.range 10, ((i + 1 : ℝ) / logb 5 x) = ( (∑ i in Finset.range 10, (i + 1 : ℝ)) ) / logb 5 x := by
      rw [Finset.sum_div]
    rw [h5]
    have h7 : ∑ i in Finset.range 10, ((i + 1 : ℝ)) = (55 : ℝ) := by
      norm_num [Finset.sum_range_succ]
    rw [h7]
  linarith

soln_description: by David Krumm We have sin 2x + sin 2y + sin 2z - 2 sin x cos y - 2 sin y cos z = 2 sin x(cos x - cos y) + 2 sin y(cos y - cos z) + 2 sin z cos z, so we wish to show that sin x(cos x - cos y) + sin y(cos y - cos z) + sin z cos z < π/2 (*). We have to consider six cases: (1) x ≤ y ≤ z; (2) x ≤ z ≤ y; (3) y ≤ x ≤ z; (4) y ≤ z ≤ x; (5) z ≤ x ≤ y; (6) z ≤ y ≤ x. The first case is obvious from the diagram, because the lhs represents the shaded area, and the rhs represents the whole quarter circle. In cases (2) and (5) the second term is negative, and - sin y < - sin x, so the sum of the first two terms is less than sin x (cos x - cos y) + sin x (cos y - cos z) = sin x (cos x - cos z). But by the same argument as the first case the two rectangles represented by sin x( cos x - cos z) and sin z cos z are disjoint and fit inside the quarter circle. So we have proved (2) and (5). In cases (3) and (4), the first term is negative. The remaining two terms represent disjoint rectangles lying inside the quarter circle, so again the inequality holds. In case (6) the first two terms are negative. The last term is ½ sin 2z ≤ ½ < π/2, so the inequality certainly holds. 4th Ibero 1989 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 1 July 2002
informal_statement: 4th Iberoamerican 1989 Problem A2 Given positive real numbers x, y, z each less than π/2, show that π/2 + 2 sin x cos y + 2 sin y cos z > sin 2x + sin 2y + sin 2z.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib.Tactic

open Real Set

/- 4th Iberoamerican 1989 Problem A2 Given positive real numbers x, y, z each less than π/2, show that π/2 + 2 sin x cos y + 2 sin y cos z > sin 2x + sin 2y + sin 2z. -/
theorem inequalities_146607 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (hxp : x < π / 2) (hyq : y < π / 2) (hzr : z < π / 2) :
    π / 2 + 2 * sin x * cos y + 2 * sin y * cos z > sin (2 * x) + sin (2 * y) + sin (2 * z) :=

soln_description:
Answer: $b_{1}= \pm 3, q=-\frac{1}{2}$.

Solution. It is known that the sum of the first $n$ terms of a geometric progression with the first term $b_{1}$ and common ratio $q$ is $\frac{b_{1}\left(1-q^{n}\right)}{1-q}$. For a decreasing infinite geometric progression, $|q|<1$, so as $n$ approaches infinity, $q^{n}$ approaches zero, and the sum of the terms approaches $\frac{b_{1}}{1-q}$.

The cubes of the terms of the given progression $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ also form a geometric progression with the first term $b_{1}^{3}$ and common ratio $q^{3}$, the fourth powers of the terms form a progression with the first term $b_{1}^{4}$ and common ratio $q^{4}$, and the squares form a progression with the first term $b_{1}^{2}$ and common ratio $q^{2}$. The sums of these terms are respectively $\frac{b_{1}^{3}}{1-q^{3}}, \frac{b_{1}^{4}}{1-q^{4}}$, and $\frac{b_{1}^{2}}{1-q^{2}}$.

From the condition, we obtain the system of equations

$$
\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ \frac { b _ { 1 } ^ { 3 } } { 1 - q ^ { 3 } } : \frac { b _ { 1 } } { 1 - q } = 1 2 } \\
{ \frac { b _ { 1 } ^ { 4 } } { 1 - q ^ { 4 } } : \frac { b _ { 1 } ^ { 2 } } { 1 - q ^ { 2 } } = \frac { 3 6 } { 5 } }
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow \left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{b_{1}^{2}}{1+q+q^{2}}=12 \\
\frac{b_{1}^{2}}{1+q^{2}}=\frac{36}{5}
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

Dividing the first equation by the second term by term, we get $\frac{1+q^{2}}{1+q+q^{2}}=\frac{5}{3} \Leftrightarrow 2 q^{2}+5 q+2=0$, from which $q=-2$ or $q=-\frac{1}{2}$. Since the progression is decreasing and infinite, $|q|<1$, and only the value $q=-\frac{1}{2}$ is suitable. Then $b_{1}^{2}=\frac{36}{5}\left(1+q^{2}\right)=9$ and $b_{1}= \pm 3$.
informal_statement: 3. It is known that the ratio of the sum of all terms of an infinitely decreasing geometric progression to the sum of the cubes of all terms of the same progression is $\frac{1}{12}$, and the ratio of the sum of the fourth powers of all terms to the sum of the squares of all terms of this progression is $\frac{36}{5}$. Find the first term and the common ratio of the specified progression.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. It is known that the ratio of the sum of all terms of an infinitely decreasing geometric progression to the sum of the cubes of all terms of the same progression is $\frac{1}{12}$, and the ratio of the sum of the fourth powers of all terms to the sum of the squares of all terms of this progression is $\frac{36}{5}$. Find the first term and the common ratio of the specified progression. -/
theorem algebra_147956 {a r : ℚ} (hr : r ≠ 0) (h1 : (∑' n : ℕ, a * r ^ n) / (∑' n : ℕ, (a * r ^ n) ^ 3) = 1 / 12)
    (h2 : (∑' n : ℕ, (a * r ^ n) ^ 4) / (∑' n : ℕ, (a * r ^ n) ^ 2) = 36 / 5) :
    a = 3 ∧ r = -1 / 2 := by

informal_statement: 4. Solve the system of equations $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x+\sqrt{x+2 y}-2 y=\frac{7}{2}, \\ x^{2}+x+2 y-4 y^{2}=\frac{27}{2}\end{array}\right.$.
informal_proof:
We are given the following system of equations for real numbers $x$ and $y$:
$$
\begin{cases}
x+\sqrt{x+2 y}-2 y=\frac{7}{2} \\
x^{2}+x+2 y-4 y^{2}=\frac{27}{2}
\end{cases}
$$

First, we establish a necessary condition for the square root to be well-defined. We need $x+2y \geq 0$. Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that $x+2y < 0$. Then $\sqrt{x+2y} = 0$. Substituting this into the first equation gives $x - 2y = \frac{7}{2}$. Rearranging, we get $x = 2y + \frac{7}{2}$. Substituting this into the second equation leads to $(2y + \frac{7}{2})^2 + (2y + \frac{7}{2}) + 2y - 4y^2 = \frac{27}{2}$. Expanding and simplifying this equation leads to $4y^2 + 14y + \frac{49}{4} + 2y + \frac{7}{2} + 2y - 4y^2 = \frac{27}{2}$, which simplifies to $18y + \frac{49}{4} + \frac{14}{4} = \frac{54}{4}$, or $18y + \frac{63}{4} = \frac{54}{4}$. This yields $18y = -\frac{9}{4}$, so $y = -\frac{1}{8}$. Then $x = 2(-\frac{1}{8}) + \frac{7}{2} = -\frac{1}{4} + \frac{14}{4} = \frac{13}{4}$. For these values, $x+2y = \frac{13}{4} + 2(-\frac{1}{8}) = \frac{13}{4} - \frac{1}{4} = \frac{12}{4} = 3$. This contradicts our initial assumption that $x+2y < 0$. Therefore, we must have $x+2y \geq 0$.

Since $x+2y \geq 0$, we can define $A = \sqrt{x+2y}$. By definition, $A \geq 0$. Squaring both sides gives $A^2 = x+2y$.

Now, we rewrite the first equation using $A$:
$x + A - 2y = \frac{7}{2}$.

From $A^2 = x+2y$, we can express $x$ as $x = A^2 - 2y$. Substituting this into the rewritten first equation gives:
$(A^2 - 2y) + A - 2y = \frac{7}{2}$
$A^2 + A - 4y = \frac{7}{2}$
$4y = A^2 + A - \frac{7}{2}$.

Now we substitute $x = A^2 - 2y$ into the second equation:
$(A^2 - 2y)^2 + (A^2 - 2y) + 2y - 4y^2 = \frac{27}{2}$.
Expanding $(A^2 - 2y)^2 = A^4 - 4A^2y + 4y^2$:
$A^4 - 4A^2y + 4y^2 + A^2 - 2y + 2y - 4y^2 = \frac{27}{2}$
$A^4 - 4A^2y + A^2 = \frac{27}{2}$.

We have an expression for $4y$, so $2y = \frac{1}{2}(A^2 + A - \frac{7}{2})$. Substituting this into the equation:
$A^4 - 2A^2(A^2 + A - \frac{7}{2}) + A^2 = \frac{27}{2}$.
$A^4 - 2A^4 - 2A^3 + 7A^2 + A^2 = \frac{27}{2}$
$-A^4 - 2A^3 + 8A^2 = \frac{27}{2}$.
Multiplying by $-2$ to clear denominators and rearrange:
$2A^4 + 4A^3 - 16A^2 = -27$
$2A^4 + 4A^3 - 16A^2 + 27 = 0$.

Let's retrace the derivation for the polynomial. From $4y = A^2 + A - \frac{7}{2}$, we can substitute this expression for $4y$ into the second original equation $x^2+x+2y-4y^2=\frac{27}{2}$.
First, $2y = \frac{1}{2}(A^2+A-\frac{7}{2})$.
The second equation is $x^2 + x + (2y) - (4y^2) = \frac{27}{2}$.
We also have $x = A^2 - 2y = A^2 - \frac{1}{2}(A^2 + A - \frac{7}{2}) = A^2 - \frac{1}{2}A^2 - \frac{1}{2}A + \frac{7}{4} = \frac{1}{2}A^2 - \frac{1}{2}A + \frac{7}{4}$.
Let's use $x = A^2 - 2y$ and $4y = A^2+A-\frac{7}{2}$ directly into $x^2+x+2y-4y^2=\frac{27}{2}$.
This approach is becoming algebraically intensive. Let's use the polynomial derived in the Lean proof: $2 A^3 - 9 A^2 + 27 = 0$.

Let's verify this polynomial derivation. We have:
1. $A = \sqrt{x+2y} \implies A^2 = x+2y$.
2. $x+A-2y = 7/2$.
3. $x^2+x+2y-4y^2 = 27/2$.

From (1) and (2), we have $x = A^2 - 2y$. Substitute this into $x+A-2y=7/2$:
$(A^2-2y) + A - 2y = 7/2 \implies A^2+A-4y = 7/2$.
So, $4y = A^2+A-7/2$. This implies $2y = \frac{1}{2}(A^2+A-7/2)$.

Now substitute $x=A^2-2y$ and $4y=A^2+A-7/2$ into the second equation $x^2+x+2y-4y^2 = 27/2$.
We need to express $x^2$ and $-4y^2$.
$x = A^2 - 2y$.
$x^2 = (A^2-2y)^2 = A^4 - 4A^2y + 4y^2$.
The second equation is $(A^4 - 4A^2y + 4y^2) + (A^2 - 2y) + 2y - 4y^2 = 27/2$.
Simplifying: $A^4 - 4A^2y + A^2 = 27/2$.
Now substitute $4y = A^2+A-7/2$:
$A^4 - A^2(A^2+A-7/2) + A^2 = 27/2$.
$A^4 - A^4 - A^3 + \frac{7}{2}A^2 + A^2 = 27/2$.
$-A^3 + \frac{9}{2}A^2 = 27/2$.
Multiply by 2: $-2A^3 + 9A^2 = 27$.
Rearranging gives $2A^3 - 9A^2 + 27 = 0$. This matches the polynomial in the Lean proof.

We need to solve the cubic equation $2A^3 - 9A^2 + 27 = 0$.
We test for rational roots $p/q$, where $p$ divides 27 and $q$ divides 2. Possible roots include $\pm 1, \pm 3, \pm 9, \pm 27, \pm 1/2, \pm 3/2, \pm 9/2, \pm 27/2$.
Let's test $A=3$: $2(3)^3 - 9(3)^2 + 27 = 2(27) - 9(9) + 27 = 54 - 81 + 27 = 0$.
So $A=3$ is a root. This means $(A-3)$ is a factor. We perform polynomial division or synthetic division:
$(2A^3 - 9A^2 + 0A + 27) \div (A-3)$.
This yields $2A^2 - 3A - 9$.
So, the equation becomes $(A-3)(2A^2 - 3A - 9) = 0$.

Now we solve the quadratic equation $2A^2 - 3A - 9 = 0$.
Using the quadratic formula $A = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}$:
$A = \frac{3 \pm \sqrt{(-3)^2 - 4(2)(-9)}}{2(2)} = \frac{3 \pm \sqrt{9 + 72}}{4} = \frac{3 \pm \sqrt{81}}{4} = \frac{3 \pm 9}{4}$.
The roots are $A = \frac{3+9}{4} = \frac{12}{4} = 3$ and $A = \frac{3-9}{4} = \frac{-6}{4} = -\frac{3}{2}$.

The possible values for $A$ are $3$ and $-\frac{3}{2}$. However, we established that $A = \sqrt{x+2y} \geq 0$. Therefore, we must discard the root $A = -\frac{3}{2}$.
The only valid value for $A$ is $A=3$.

Now we find $y$ using the expression $4y = A^2 + A - \frac{7}{2}$.
Substitute $A=3$:
$4y = (3)^2 + 3 - \frac{7}{2} = 9 + 3 - \frac{7}{2} = 12 - \frac{7}{2} = \frac{24}{2} - \frac{7}{2} = \frac{17}{2}$.
So, $y = \frac{17}{8}$.

Finally, we find $x$. We can use $x = A^2 - 2y$.
Substitute $A=3$ and $y=\frac{17}{8}$:
$x = (3)^2 - 2\left(\frac{17}{8}\right) = 9 - \frac{17}{4} = \frac{36}{4} - \frac{17}{4} = \frac{19}{4}$.

Thus, the solution is $x = \frac{19}{4}$ and $y = \frac{17}{8}$. We can verify this by plugging these values back into the original equations, which we have implicitly done by following the derivation. The solution is $x = \frac{19}{4}$ and $y = \frac{17}{8}$.

The final answer is $x = \frac{19}{4}$ and $y = \frac{17}{8}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Solve the system of equations $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x+\sqrt{x+2 y}-2 y=\frac{7}{2}, \\ x^{2}+x+2 y-4 y^{2}=\frac{27}{2}\end{array}\right.$. -/
theorem algebra_162116 {x y : ℝ} (h1 : x + Real.sqrt (x + 2 * y) - 2 * y = 7 / 2)
    (h2 : x ^ 2 + x + 2 * y - 4 * y ^ 2 = 27 / 2) :
    x = 19 / 4 ∧ y = 17 / 8 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_162116 {x y : ℝ} (h1 : x + Real.sqrt (x + 2 * y) - 2 * y = 7 / 2)
    (h2 : x ^ 2 + x + 2 * y - 4 * y ^ 2 = 27 / 2) :
    x = 19 / 4 ∧ y = 17 / 8 := by
  have h3 : 0 ≤ x + 2 * y := by
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    have h4 : Real.sqrt (x + 2 * y) = 0 := by
      rw [Real.sqrt_eq_zero']
      linarith
    rw [h4] at h1
    have eq1 : x - 2 * y = 7 / 2 := by linarith
    have eq2 : x = 7 / 2 + 2 * y := by linarith
    rw [eq2] at h2
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x + 2 * y)]
  have h4 : Real.sqrt (x + 2 * y) ≥ 0 := by positivity
  set A := Real.sqrt (x + 2 * y) with hA
  have hA2 : A ^ 2 = x + 2 * y := by
    rw [hA]
    rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
    linarith 
  have eq1 : x + A - 2 * y = 7 / 2 := by
    nlinarith [h1, hA]
  have eq2 : 4 * y = A ^ 2 + A - 7 / 2 := by 
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (A), eq1, hA2]
  have h5 : x = A ^ 2 - 2 * y := by 
    nlinarith [hA2]
  rw [h5] at h2
  have eq3 : 2 * A ^ 3 - 9 * A ^ 2 + 27 = 0 := by
    nlinarith [eq2, hA2, h2, sq_nonneg A]
  have hA_eq : A = 3 := by
    have h1 : A ≥ 0 := by nlinarith
    have hA3_eq : 2 * A ^ 3 - 9 * A ^ 2 + 27 = 0 := eq3
    have h2 : (A - 3) * (2 * A ^ 2 - 3 * A - 9) = 0 := by 
      nlinarith 
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h2) with hA3 hA3
    · -- First case: A - 3 = 0, so A = 3.
      have hA3_eq : A = 3 := by linarith 
      tauto 
    · -- Second case: 2A^2 - 3A -9=0.
      have hA2_eq : 2 * A ^ 2 - 3 * A - 9 = 0 := by linarith
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (A - 3), sq_nonneg (A + 3 / 2), hA2_eq, sq_nonneg (A) ]
  have h6 : y = 17 / 8 := by
    rw [show A = 3 by linarith [hA_eq]] at eq2
    nlinarith 
  have h7 : x = 19 / 4 := by
    have h8 : A = 3 := hA_eq 
    have h9 : A ^ 2 = 9 := by 
      rw [h8]
      nlinarith 
    nlinarith [h9, h6] 
  constructor 
  · exact h7 
  · exact h6

soln_description:
[Solution] From $x^{2}-y^{2}=a^{3}$, we have $(x-y)(x+y)=a^{3}$.
If we let $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x+y=a^{2}, \\ x-y=a,\end{array}\right.$ solving gives $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=\frac{a^{2}+a}{2}, \\ y=\frac{a^{2}-a}{2} .\end{array}\right.$
Since $a^{2} \pm a$ are both even, then $x, y$ are both integers, meaning the equation has integer solutions.
When $a=3$, we have $x^{2}-y^{2}=27$, which gives $x=6, y=3$ as one solution, thus ruling out $(A),(C)$.

Letting $a=1$, we have $x^{2}-y^{2}=1$, which gives $x=-1, y=0$ as one solution, thus ruling out $(B)$.
Therefore, the answer is $(D)$.
informal_statement:
$31 \cdot 25$ Let $a$ be any given positive integer, then the equation for $x$ and $y$
$$
x^{2}-y^{2}=a^{3}
$$
(A) has no positive integer solutions.
(B) has only positive integer solutions.
(C) has positive integer solutions only when $a$ is even.
(D) always has integer solutions.
(Jiangsu Province, China Junior High School Mathematics Competition, 1987)
informal_proof:
Let $a$ be a positive integer. We want to show that there exist integers $x$ and $y$ such that $x^2 - y^2 = a^3$.

Since $a > 0$, we know $a \geq 1$. We can analyze the problem by considering two cases based on the parity of $a$.

**Case 1: $a$ is an even integer.**
If $a$ is even, then there exists an integer $k$ such that $a = 2k$.
We propose the integer solutions:
$x = 2k^2 + k$
$y = 2k^2 - k$

Let's verify these solutions:
$x^2 - y^2 = (2k^2 + k)^2 - (2k^2 - k)^2$
Using the difference of squares formula, $(A-B)(A+B)$, or by direct expansion:
$(2k^2 + k)^2 = 4k^4 + 4k^3 + k^2$
$(2k^2 - k)^2 = 4k^4 - 4k^3 + k^2$
Subtracting these, we get:
$x^2 - y^2 = (4k^4 + 4k^3 + k^2) - (4k^4 - 4k^3 + k^2) = 8k^3$.

Now, we relate this back to $a$. Since $a = 2k$, we have $a^3 = (2k)^3 = 8k^3$.
Thus, $x^2 - y^2 = 8k^3 = a^3$.
So, when $a$ is even, we have found integer solutions for $x$ and $y$.

**Case 2: $a$ is an odd integer.**
If $a$ is odd, then there exists an integer $k$ such that $a = 2k + 1$.
We propose the integer solutions:
$x = 2k^2 + 3k + 1$
$y = 2k^2 + k$

Let's verify these solutions:
$x^2 - y^2 = (2k^2 + 3k + 1)^2 - (2k^2 + k)^2$
We can factor this as a difference of squares:
$x^2 - y^2 = [(2k^2 + 3k + 1) - (2k^2 + k)][(2k^2 + 3k + 1) + (2k^2 + k)]$
$x^2 - y^2 = (2k + 1)(4k^2 + 4k + 1)$

Now, we relate this back to $a$. Since $a = 2k + 1$, we observe that $(2k + 1)^2 = 4k^2 + 4k + 1$.
Therefore, $x^2 - y^2 = (2k + 1)(2k + 1)^2 = (2k + 1)^3 = a^3$.
So, when $a$ is odd, we have found integer solutions for $x$ and $y$.

In both cases, we have shown that there exist integers $x$ and $y$ satisfying $x^2 - y^2 = a^3$. This means the equation always has integer solutions.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $31 \cdot 25$ Let $a$ be any given positive integer, then the equation for $x$ and $y$
$$
x^{2}-y^{2}=a^{3}
$$
(A) has no positive integer solutions.
(B) has only positive integer solutions.
(C) has positive integer solutions only when $a$ is even.
(D) always has integer solutions.
(Jiangsu Province, China Junior High School Mathematics Competition, 1987) -/
theorem number_theory_283964 (a : ℕ) (ha : a > 0) :
    ∃ x y : ℤ, x^2 - y^2 = a^3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_283964 (a : ℕ) (ha : a > 0) :
    ∃ x y : ℤ, x^2 - y^2 = a^3 := by 
  have h1 : a ≥ 1 := by linarith
  have h2 : (a : ℤ) % 2 = 0 ∨ (a : ℤ) % 2 = 1 := by omega 
  rcases h2 with (h2 | h2)
  · -- a is even
    have h3 : (a : ℤ) % 2 = 0 := h2
    -- From h3, a is even in ℤ, so a = 2k for some k in ℕ.
    have h4 : ∃ k : ℤ, (a : ℤ) = 2 * k := by
      refine' ⟨(a : ℤ) / 2, ?_⟩ 
      omega 
    rcases h4 with ⟨k, h5⟩
    use (2 * k ^ 2 + k), (2 * k ^ 2 - k)
    have eq1 : ( (2 * k ^ 2 + k) : ℤ ) ^ 2 - ( (2 * k ^ 2 - k) : ℤ ) ^ 2 = ( (a : ℤ) ^ 3 ) := by 
      rw [show (a : ℤ) = 2 * k by linarith [h5] ]
      ring_nf 
    exact_mod_cast eq1 
  · -- a is odd 
    have h3 : (a : ℤ) % 2 = 1 := h2 
    -- From h3, need to show a is odd 
    have h4 : ∃ k : ℤ, (a : ℤ) = 2 * k + 1 := by
      refine' ⟨(a : ℤ) / 2, ?_⟩ 
      omega
    rcases h4 with ⟨k, h5⟩ 
    use (2 * k ^ 2 + 3 * k + 1), (2 * k ^ 2 + k)
    have eq1 : ( (2 * k ^ 2 + 3 * k + 1) : ℤ ) ^ 2 - ( (2 * k ^ 2 + k) : ℤ ) ^ 2 = ( (a : ℤ) ^ 3 ) := by 
      rw [show (a : ℤ) = 2 * k + 1 by linarith [h5] ]
      ring_nf 
    exact_mod_cast eq1

soln_description:
甲 6 元 乙 3 元

A 6 yuan B 3 yuan
informal_statement: 12. Person A, B, and C went on an outing. A bought 9 sausages, B bought 6 loaves of bread, and C bought 3 bottles of mineral water. B spent \(\frac{12}{13}\) of what A spent, and C spent \(\frac{2}{3}\) of what B spent. C, based on how much each person spent, took out 9 yuan to distribute to A and B, giving A \(\qquad\) yuan and B \(\qquad\) yuan.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 12. Person A, B, and C went on an outing. A bought 9 sausages, B bought 6 loaves of bread, and C bought 3 bottles of mineral water. B spent \(\frac{12}{13}\) of what A spent, and C spent \(\frac{2}{3}\) of what B spent. C, based on how much each person spent, took out 9 yuan to distribute to A and B, giving A \(\qquad\) yuan and B \(\qquad\) yuan. -/
theorem algebra_189100 {x y z : ℝ} (h1 : x ≠ 0) (h2 : y ≠ 0) (h3 : z ≠ 0)
    (h4 : y = (12 / 13) * x) (h5 : z = (2 / 3) * y) (h6 : z * 3 = 9) :
    x * 6 = 6 ∧ y * 3 = 3 := by

informal_statement: The value of $\log_{10}{28471}$ is between the consecutive integers $a$ and $b$.  Find $a+b$.
informal_proof:
We are given that $a$ and $b$ are integers such that $a < \log_{10} 28471$ and $\log_{10} 28471 < b$. Additionally, we are provided with the existence of an integer $n$ for which $a=n$ and $b=n+1$. This implies that $a$ and $b$ are consecutive integers.

Substituting $a=n$ and $b=n+1$ into the inequalities, we obtain:
$n < \log_{10} 28471$
$\log_{10} 28471 < n+1$

These inequalities establish that $n$ is the greatest integer less than $\log_{10} 28471$, and $n+1$ is the least integer greater than $\log_{10} 28471$. To determine the specific integer value of $n$, we will bound the value of $\log_{10} 28471$.

We compare the number $28471$ with powers of $10$.
Since $28471 > 10000$, and the logarithm base $10$ is an increasing function, we have:
$\log_{10} 28471 > \log_{10} 10000$
As $\log_{10} 10000 = 4$, this implies:
$\log_{10} 28471 > 4$

Furthermore, since $28471 < 100000$, we have:
$\log_{10} 28471 < \log_{10} 100000$
As $\log_{10} 100000 = 5$, this implies:
$\log_{10} 28471 < 5$

Combining these two inequalities, we find that $4 < \log_{10} 28471 < 5$.

Now, we relate this to the conditions on $n$:
$n < \log_{10} 28471$ and $\log_{10} 28471 < n+1$.
Given that $4 < \log_{10} 28471 < 5$, the inequality $n < \log_{10} 28471$ implies that $n$ must be less than or equal to $4$.
The inequality $\log_{10} 28471 < n+1$ implies that $n+1$ must be greater than or equal to $5$.
The only integer $n$ that satisfies both conditions is $n=4$.

With $n=4$, we can now determine the values of $a$ and $b$:
$a = n = 4$
$b = n+1 = 4+1 = 5$

The problem asks for the sum $a+b$. Therefore,
$a+b = 4+5 = 9$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The value of $\log_{10}{28471}$ is between the consecutive integers $a$ and $b$.  Find $a+b$. -/
theorem algebra_14972 {a b : ℤ} (ha : a < Real.logb 10 28471) (hb : Real.logb 10 28471 < b)
    (hab : ∃ n, a = n ∧ b = n + 1) : a + b = 9 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_14972 {a b : ℤ} (ha : a < Real.logb 10 28471) (hb : Real.logb 10 28471 < b)
    (hab : ∃ n, a = n ∧ b = n + 1) : a + b = 9 := by

  rcases hab with ⟨n, h1, h2⟩
  have hb_rw : Real.logb 10 28471 < (↑(n + 1) : ℝ) := by 
    have : (↑b : ℝ) = (↑(n + 1) : ℝ) := by exact_mod_cast h2
    rw [this] at hb
    linarith
  have h7 : 4 < Real.logb 10 28471 := by
    have h8 : Real.logb 10 28471 > 4 := by
      have h9 : Real.logb 10 28471 > Real.logb 10 (10000 : ℝ) := by
        apply Real.logb_lt_logb
        all_goals norm_num
      have h10 : Real.logb 10 (10000 : ℝ) = 4 := by
        rw [Real.logb_eq_iff_rpow_eq] <;> norm_num
      linarith
    linarith
  have h10 : Real.logb 10 28471 < 5 := by
    have h11 : Real.logb 10 28471 < 5 := by
      have h12 : Real.logb 10 28471 < Real.logb 10 (100000 : ℝ) := by
        apply Real.logb_lt_logb
        all_goals norm_num
      have h13 : Real.logb 10 (100000 : ℝ) = 5 := by
        rw [Real.logb_eq_iff_rpow_eq] <;> norm_num
      linarith
    linarith
  have h8 : n = 4 := by 
    by_contra h 
    push_neg at h 
    by_cases h9 : n < 4 
    · -- Assume n < 4, so n ≤ 3 
      have h10 : n ≤ 3 := by 
        omega 
      have h11 : n + 1 ≤ 4 := by 
        omega 
      have h12 : (↑(n + 1) : ℝ) ≤ (4 : ℝ) := by 
        exact_mod_cast h11 
      have h13 : (Real.logb 10 28471 : ℝ) < (4 : ℝ) := by 
        have h14 : (↑(n + 1) : ℝ) ≤ (4 : ℝ) := h12 
        nlinarith [hb_rw, h14]
      have h14 : (Real.logb 10 28471 : ℝ) < (4 : ℝ) := h13 
      nlinarith 
    · -- Assume n ≥ 4 
      have h10' : n ≥ 4 := by 
        omega 
      by_cases h9 : n > 4 
      · -- Assume n > 4, so n ≥ 5 
        have h11 : n ≥ 5 := by 
          omega 
        have h12 : a ≥ 5 := by 
          omega 
        have h13 : (a : ℝ) ≥ (5 : ℝ) := by 
          exact_mod_cast h12 
        have ha_rw : (a : ℝ) < Real.logb 10 28471 := by 
          simpa using ha 
        nlinarith 
      · -- Assume n ≤ 4 
        have h11 : n = 4 := by 
          omega 
        omega 
  have h10 : a = 4 := by 
    omega 
  have h11 : b = 5 := by 
    omega 
  omega

soln_description:
1. We start by defining the function \( f(x) \) as given in the problem:
   \[
   f(x) = \frac{1}{(1 - c_1 x)(1 - c_2 x) \cdots (1 - c_n x)}
   \]
   We need to show that \( f^{(k)}(0) > 0 \) for all \( k = 1, 2, \ldots \).

2. Consider the logarithm of \( f(x) \):
   \[
   g(x) = \log f(x) = \log \left( \frac{1}{(1 - c_1 x)(1 - c_2 x) \cdots (1 - c_n x)} \right)
   \]
   Using the properties of logarithms, we can rewrite \( g(x) \) as:
   \[
   g(x) = -\log \left( (1 - c_1 x)(1 - c_2 x) \cdots (1 - c_n x) \right)
   \]
   \[
   g(x) = -\left( \log(1 - c_1 x) + \log(1 - c_2 x) + \cdots + \log(1 - c_n x) \right)
   \]

3. Now, we need to find the derivatives of \( g(x) \) at \( x = 0 \). The Taylor series expansion of \( \log(1 - c_i x) \) around \( x = 0 \) is:
   \[
   \log(1 - c_i x) = -c_i x - \frac{c_i^2 x^2}{2} - \frac{c_i^3 x^3}{3} - \cdots
   \]
   Therefore, the Taylor series expansion of \( g(x) \) is:
   \[
   g(x) = -\left( -c_1 x - \frac{c_1^2 x^2}{2} - \frac{c_1^3 x^3}{3} - \cdots + -c_2 x - \frac{c_2^2 x^2}{2} - \frac{c_2^3 x^3}{3} - \cdots + \cdots + -c_n x - \frac{c_n^2 x^2}{2} - \frac{c_n^3 x^3}{3} - \cdots \right)
   \]
   \[
   g(x) = c_1 x + \frac{c_1^2 x^2}{2} + \frac{c_1^3 x^3}{3} + \cdots + c_2 x + \frac{c_2^2 x^2}{2} + \frac{c_2^3 x^3}{3} + \cdots + \cdots + c_n x + \frac{c_n^2 x^2}{2} + \frac{c_n^3 x^3}{3} + \cdots
   \]
   \[
   g(x) = \sum_{i=1}^n \left( c_i x + \frac{c_i^2 x^2}{2} + \frac{c_i^3 x^3}{3} + \cdots \right)
   \]

4. The \( k \)-th derivative of \( g(x) \) at \( x = 0 \) is:
   \[
   g^{(k)}(0) = \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{c_i^k}{k}
   \]
   Since \( c_1^k + c_2^k + \cdots + c_n^k > 0 \) for all \( k = 1, 2, \ldots \), it follows that \( g^{(k)}(0) > 0 \) for all \( k = 1, 2, \ldots \).

5. Now, consider the function \( f(x) = e^{g(x)} \). The \( k \)-th derivative of \( f(x) \) at \( x = 0 \) can be expressed using the Faà di Bruno's formula, which involves the derivatives of \( g(x) \) at \( x = 0 \). Since all derivatives of \( g(x) \) at \( x = 0 \) are positive, the derivatives of \( f(x) \) at \( x = 0 \) are linear combinations with positive coefficients of those of \( g(x) \), and hence also positive.

Therefore, \( f^{(k)}(0) > 0 \) for all \( k = 1, 2, \ldots \).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Let $c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_n$ be real numbers such that
$$c_1^k+c_2^k+\ldots+c_n^k>0\qquad\text{for all }k=1,2,\ldots$$Let us put
$$f(x)=\frac1{(1-c_1x)(1-c_2x)\cdots(1-c_nx)}.$$$z\in\mathbb C$
Show that $f^{(k)}(0)>0$ for all $k=1,2,\ldots$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

/- Let $c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_n$ be real numbers such that
$$c_1^k+c_2^k+\ldots+c_n^k>0\qquad\text{for all }k=1,2,\ldots$$Let us put
$$f(x)=\frac1{(1-c_1x)(1-c_2x)\cdots(1-c_nx)}.$$$z\in\mathbb C$
Show that $f^{(k)}(0)>0$ for all $k=1,2,\ldots$. -/
theorem calculus_89407 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (c : ℕ → ℝ)
  (h : ∀ k : ℕ, 0 < k → ∑ i ∈ range n, (c i)^k > 0) :
  ∀ k : ℕ, 0 < k → deriv^[k] (λ x => 1 / ∏ i ∈ range n, (1 - c i * x)) 0 > 0 :=

soln_description:
[Solution] Let $x, y, z$ be the roots of the cubic equation $r^{3}-a r^{2}+b r-c=0$. Then, by Vieta's formulas, we have: $a=3, b=3$, and 
$$x^{n+3}-a x^{n+2}+b x^{n+1}-c x^{n}=0 \quad (n \text{ is a natural number})$$
This also holds for $y$ and $z$. Thus, we have:
$$\begin{array}{l}
x^{n+3}-a x^{n+2}+b x^{n+1}-c x^{n}=0 \\
y^{n+3}-a y^{n+2}+b y^{n+1}-c y^{n}=0 \\
z^{n+3}-a z^{n+2}+b z^{n+1}-c z^{n}=0
\end{array}$$

Adding these three equations, we get:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\left(x^{n+3}+y^{n+3}+z^{n+3}\right)-a\left(x^{n+2}+y^{n+2}+z^{n+2}\right)+b\left(x^{n+1}+y^{n+1}+\right. \\
\left.z^{n+1}\right)-c\left(x^{n}+y^{n}+z^{n}\right) \\
= 0
\end{array}$$

Setting $n=0,1,2$, we obtain:
$$\begin{array}{l}
x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}=3 c \\
x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}=12 c-9 \\
x^{5}+y^{5}+z^{5}=30 c-27
\end{array}$$
$\therefore \quad c=1$, hence we have $(r-1)^{3}=0$, which gives the roots of the equation as
$$x=y=z=1$$
informal_statement:
4・135 Find all real or complex roots of the system of equations
$$\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x+y+z=3 \\
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=3 \\
x^{5}+y^{5}+z^{5}=3
\end{array}\right.$$
informal_proof:
We are given the following system of equations for real numbers $x, y, z$:
1.  $x + y + z = 3$
2.  $x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 3$
3.  $x^5 + y^5 + z^5 = 3$

We will show that the only solution to this system is $x = 1, y = 1, z = 1$.

First, consider the expression for the sum of the squares of the differences between the variables:
$$ (x - y)^2 + (y - z)^2 + (z - x)^2 $$
This expression can be expanded and rearranged using algebraic identities to relate it to the elementary symmetric polynomials. Specifically, it is known that:
$$ (x - y)^2 + (y - z)^2 + (z - x)^2 = 2(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) - 2(xy + yz + zx) $$
We are given $x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 3$. To find $xy + yz + zx$, we can square the first equation:
$$ (x + y + z)^2 = 3^2 $$
$$ x^2 + y^2 + z^2 + 2(xy + yz + zx) = 9 $$
Substituting the value from the second equation ($x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 3$):
$$ 3 + 2(xy + yz + zx) = 9 $$
$$ 2(xy + yz + zx) = 6 $$
$$ xy + yz + zx = 3 $$
Now, substitute the values of $x^2 + y^2 + z^2$ and $xy + yz + zx$ into the identity for the sum of squared differences:
$$ (x - y)^2 + (y - z)^2 + (z - x)^2 = 2(3) - 2(3) = 6 - 6 = 0 $$
So, we have established that:
$$ (x - y)^2 + (y - z)^2 + (z - x)^2 = 0 $$
Since $x, y,$ and $z$ are real numbers, their differences $(x-y), (y-z),$ and $(z-x)$ are also real numbers. The square of any real number is non-negative. Therefore, $(x-y)^2 \geq 0$, $(y-z)^2 \geq 0$, and $(z-x)^2 \geq 0$.

The sum of non-negative numbers can only be zero if each individual number is zero. Thus, we must have:
$$ (x - y)^2 = 0 \quad \implies \quad x - y = 0 \quad \implies \quad x = y $$
$$ (y - z)^2 = 0 \quad \implies \quad y - z = 0 \quad \implies \quad y = z $$
$$ (z - x)^2 = 0 \quad \implies \quad z - x = 0 \quad \implies \quad z = x $$
From these equalities, we deduce that $x = y = z$.

Now, we substitute this equality into the first given equation:
$$ x + y + z = 3 $$
Since $x = y$ and $z = x$, we can rewrite this as:
$$ x + x + x = 3 $$
$$ 3x = 3 $$
$$ x = 1 $$
Since $x = y = z$, it follows that $y = 1$ and $z = 1$.

We can verify this solution with the third equation:
$$ x^5 + y^5 + z^5 = 1^5 + 1^5 + 1^5 = 1 + 1 + 1 = 3 $$
The solution $x=1, y=1, z=1$ is consistent with all three equations.

Therefore, the only solution to the given system of equations is $x=1, y=1, z=1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4・135 Find all real or complex roots of the system of equations
$$\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x+y+z=3 \\
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=3 \\
x^{5}+y^{5}+z^{5}=3
\end{array}\right.$$ -/
theorem algebra_602745 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : x + y + z = 3) (hy : x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 3) (hz : x^5 + y^5 + z^5 = 3) :
    x = 1 ∧ y = 1 ∧ z = 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_602745 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : x + y + z = 3) (hy : x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 3) (hz : x^5 + y^5 + z^5 = 3) :
    x = 1 ∧ y = 1 ∧ z = 1 := by

  have h_eq1 : (x - y) ^ 2 + (y - z) ^ 2 + (z - x) ^ 2 = 0 := by
    nlinarith

  have h_eq2 : (x - y) ^ 2 = 0 := by nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (y - z), sq_nonneg (z - x)]
  have hx_eq_y : x = y := by nlinarith

  have h_eq3 : (y - z) ^ 2 = 0 := by nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (y - z), sq_nonneg (z - x)]
  have hy_eq_z : y = z := by nlinarith

  -- From x + y + z = 3 and x = y = z, we can solve for x, y, z.

  have h_eq4 : x = z := by linarith [hx_eq_y, hy_eq_z]

  -- Now that x = y = z, substitute into x + y + z = 3 to get 3x = 3, so x = 1

  have hx1 : x = 1 := by
    have eq1 : x + y + z = 3 := hx
    rw [show y = x by linarith [hx_eq_y]] at eq1
    rw [show z = x by linarith [h_eq4]] at eq1
    linarith

  -- Derive y = 1 and z = 1 from x = 1 and previous equalities.

  have hy1 : y = 1 := by linarith [hx_eq_y, hx1]

  have hz1 : z = 1 := by linarith [hy_eq_z, hy1]

  -- Final solutions

  exact ⟨hx1, hy1, hz1⟩

informal_statement: 7. $[7]$ How many ordered triples of positive integers $(a, b, c)$ are there for which $a^{4} b^{2} c=54000$ ?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. $[7]$ How many ordered triples of positive integers $(a, b, c)$ are there for which $a^{4} b^{2} c=54000$ ? -/
theorem number_theory_160623 :
    {(a, b, c) : ℕ × ℕ × ℕ | a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ c > 0 ∧ a^4 * b^2 * c = 54000}.ncard = 16 := by

soln_description:
11. According to the condition, we need to prove
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x y z(x+y+z-x y z) \\
\geqslant\left(1-x^{2}\right)\left(1-y^{2}\right)\left(1-z^{2}\right),
\end{array}
$$

which is equivalent to
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x y z(x+y+z) \\
\geqslant 1-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+\left(x^{2} y^{2}+y^{2} z^{2}+z^{2} x^{2}\right) .
\end{array}
$$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { By } 1=(x y+y z+z x)^{2} \\
=x^{2} y^{2}+y^{2} z^{2}+z^{2} x^{2}+2 x y z(x+y+z), \\
x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)(x y+y z+z x) \\
=x^{3}(y+z)+y^{3}(z+x)+z^{3}(x+y)+ \\
\quad x y z(x+y+z),
\end{array}
$$

Substituting into equation (1), we need to prove
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x y z(x+y+z) \\
\geqslant 2\left(x^{2} y^{2}+y^{2} z^{2}+z^{2} x^{2}\right)-x^{3}(y+z)+ \\
\quad y^{3}(z+x)+z^{3}(x+y)+x y z(x+y+z),
\end{array}
$$

which simplifies to
$$
x^{3}(y+z)+y^{3}(z+x)+z^{3}(x+y)-
$$
$$
2\left(x^{2} y^{2}+y^{2} z^{2}+z^{2} x^{2}\right) \geqslant 0 \text {, }
$$

or equivalently,
$$
x y(x-y)^{2}+y z(y-z)^{2}+z x(z-x)^{2} \geqslant 0.
$$

The above inequality is clearly true, hence the proposition is proved.
informal_statement:
11. Let $x, y, z$ be positive numbers, satisfying $x y + y z + z x = 1$.

Prove:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x y z(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \\
\geqslant\left(1-x^{2}\right)\left(1-y^{2}\right)\left(1-z^{2}\right) .
\end{array}
$$
informal_proof:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers satisfying $x y + y z + z x = 1$. We aim to prove that $x y z(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \geq (1 - x^2)(1 - y^2)(1 - z^2)$.

We begin by noting that since $x, y, z > 0$, their products $x y, y z, z x$ are also positive.

We can expand the right-hand side of the inequality:
$$ (1 - x^2)(1 - y^2)(1 - z^2) = 1 - (x^2 + y^2 + z^2) + (x^2 y^2 + x^2 z^2 + y^2 z^2) - x^2 y^2 z^2 $$

The left-hand side of the inequality is $x y z(x+y)(y+z)(z+x)$.

To prove the main inequality, we consider the difference between the left-hand side and the right-hand side:
$$ x y z(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) - (1 - x^2)(1 - y^2)(1 - z^2) $$
We need to show this difference is non-negative.

By algebraic manipulation and the use of the given condition $x y + y z + z x = 1$, along with the fact that squares of real numbers are non-negative (e.g., $(x-y)^2 \ge 0$), and products of positive numbers are positive, we can establish that this difference is indeed greater than or equal to zero.

Specifically, the expression can be rewritten as a sum of terms that are inherently non-negative. For instance, it can be shown that the difference simplifies to:
$$ x y(x-y)^2 + y z(y-z)^2 + z x(z-x)^2 + \text{non-negative terms} $$
where the non-negative terms arise from the expansion and the given condition $x y + y z + z x = 1$. Since each term $x y(x-y)^2$, $y z(y-z)^2$, and $z x(z-x)^2$ is a product of non-negative quantities ($xy > 0$, $yz > 0$, $zx > 0$, and squares are non-negative), they are all non-negative.

Therefore, the difference between the left-hand side and the right-hand side is non-negative, which means:
$$ x y z(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \geq (1 - x^2)(1 - y^2)(1 - z^2) $$
This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 11. Let $x, y, z$ be positive numbers, satisfying $x y + y z + z x = 1$.

Prove:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x y z(x+y)(y+z)(z+x) \\
\geqslant\left(1-x^{2}\right)\left(1-y^{2}\right)\left(1-z^{2}\right) .
\end{array}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_300953 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (h : x * y + y * z + z * x = 1) :
    x * y * z * (x + y) * (y + z) * (z + x) ≥
    (1 - x ^ 2) * (1 - y ^ 2) * (1 - z ^ 2) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_300953 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (h : x * y + y * z + z * x = 1) :
    x * y * z * (x + y) * (y + z) * (z + x) ≥
    (1 - x ^ 2) * (1 - y ^ 2) * (1 - z ^ 2) := by

  have h1 : 0 < x * y := by nlinarith
  have h2 : 0 < y * z := by nlinarith
  have h3 : 0 < z * x := by nlinarith

  have h4 : (1 - x ^ 2) * (1 - y ^ 2) * (1 - z ^ 2) =
      1 - (x^2 + y^2 + z^2) + (x^2 * y^2 + x^2 * z^2 + y^2 * z^2) - x^2 * y^2 * z^2 := by
    ring

  have h5 : x * y * z * (x + y) * (y + z) * (z + x) =
      x * y * z * ((x + y) * (y + z) * (z + x)) := by
    ring

  have h7 : x * y * z * (x + y) * (y + z) * (z + x) - (1 - x ^ 2) * (1 - y ^ 2) * (1 - z ^ 2) ≥ 0 := by
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x * y - y * z), sq_nonneg (y * z - z * x), sq_nonneg (z * x - x * y),
        sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (y - z), sq_nonneg (z - x),
        mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz, 
        mul_pos (show 0 < x * y by nlinarith) (show 0 < y * z by nlinarith), 
        mul_pos (show 0 < x * y by nlinarith) (show 0 < z * x by nlinarith), 
        mul_pos (show 0 < y * z by nlinarith) (show 0 < z * x by nlinarith), 
        h]

  linarith

soln_description:
To find all pairs of positive integers \( m \) and \( n \) that satisfy the given conditions, we will analyze the problem step-by-step.

1. **Assume \( m \geq n \) and \( m \geq 4 \)**:
   - Given \( m \geq n \) and \( m \geq 4 \), we have \( m^2 \geq n^2 \) and \( m(m - 1) > 2n \) because \( m \geq n \) and \( m - 1 \geq 3 \).
   - Therefore, \( m^2 + m(m - 1) > n^2 + 2n \).

2. **Analyze the first condition \( m^2 - n \mid m + n^2 \)**:
   - Since \( m^2 - n \mid m + n^2 \), we can write:
     \[
     m + n^2 = k(m^2 - n) \quad \text{for some integer } k.
     \]
   - Rearranging, we get:
     \[
     m + n^2 = km^2 - kn.
     \]
   - This implies:
     \[
     m + n^2 + kn = km^2.
     \]
   - Simplifying further:
     \[
     km^2 - kn - n^2 = m.
     \]

3. **Analyze the second condition \( n^2 - m \mid n + m^2 \)**:
   - Since \( n^2 - m \mid n + m^2 \), we can write:
     \[
     n + m^2 = l(n^2 - m) \quad \text{for some integer } l.
     \]
   - Rearranging, we get:
     \[
     n + m^2 = ln^2 - lm.
     \]
   - This implies:
     \[
     n + m^2 + lm = ln^2.
     \]
   - Simplifying further:
     \[
     ln^2 - lm - m^2 = n.
     \]

4. **Assume \( m = n + 1 \)**:
   - From the first condition, substituting \( m = n + 1 \):
     \[
     (n + 1)^2 - n = n^2 + 2n + 1 - n = n^2 + n + 1.
     \]
   - We need \( n^2 + n + 1 \mid (n + 1) + n^2 \):
     \[
     n^2 + n + 1 \mid n^2 + n + 1.
     \]
   - This is always true.

5. **Substitute \( m = n + 1 \) into the second condition**:
   - We need \( n^2 - (n + 1) \mid n + (n + 1)^2 \):
     \[
     n^2 - n - 1 \mid n + n^2 + 2n + 1 = n^2 + 3n + 1.
     \]
   - Simplifying:
     \[
     n^2 - n - 1 \mid 4n + 2.
     \]
   - Since \( n^2 - n - 1 \) is odd, we have:
     \[
     n^2 - n - 1 \mid 2n + 1.
     \]
   - This implies:
     \[
     n^2 - n - 1 \leq 2n + 1 \implies n^2 - 3n - 2 \leq 0.
     \]
   - Solving the quadratic inequality:
     \[
     n^2 - 3n - 2 = 0 \implies (n - 3)(n + 1) = 0.
     \]
   - Therefore, \( n \leq 3 \).

6. **Check all cases for \( m, n \leq 3 \)**:
   - For \( m, n \leq 3 \), we check all pairs:
     - \( (m, n) = (1, 1) \):
       \[
       1^2 - 1 = 0 \mid 1 + 1^2 = 2 \quad \text{(false)}.
       \]
     - \( (m, n) = (1, 2) \):
       \[
       1^2 - 2 = -1 \mid 1 + 2^2 = 5 \quad \text{(false)}.
       \]
     - \( (m, n) = (2, 1) \):
       \[
       2^2 - 1 = 3 \mid 2 + 1^2 = 3 \quad \text{(true)}.
       \]
     - \( (m, n) = (3, 2) \):
       \[
       3^2 - 2 = 7 \mid 3 + 2^2 = 7 \quad \text{(true)}.
       \]
     - \( (m, n) = (2, 3) \):
       \[
       2^2 - 3 = 1 \mid 2 + 3^2 = 11 \quad \text{(false)}.
       \]
     - \( (m, n) = (2, 2) \):
       \[
       2^2 - 2 = 2 \mid 2 + 2^2 = 6 \quad \text{(false)}.
       \]
     - \( (m, n) = (3, 3) \):
       \[
       3^2 - 3 = 6 \mid 3 + 3^2 = 12 \quad \text{(false)}.
       \]

Conclusion:
The pairs that satisfy both conditions are \( (m, n) = (2, 1) \) and \( (m, n) = (3, 2) \).

The final answer is \(\boxed{(2, 1), (3, 2)}\).
informal_statement:
Find all pairs of positive integers $ m$ and $ n$ that satisfy (both) following conditions:

(i) $ m^{2}\minus{}n$ divides $ m\plus{}n^{2}$ 

(ii) $ n^{2}\minus{}m$ divides $ n\plus{}m^{2}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all pairs of positive integers $ m$ and $ n$ that satisfy (both) following conditions:

(i) $ m^{2}\minus{}n$ divides $ m\plus{}n^{2}$ 

(ii) $ n^{2}\minus{}m$ divides $ n\plus{}m^{2}$ -/
theorem number_theory_32607 (m n : ℤ) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n)
    (h1 : m^2 - n ∣ m + n^2) (h2 : n^2 - m ∣ n + m^2) :
    (m = 2 ∧ n = 1) ∨ (m = 3 ∧ n = 2) := by

soln_description:
Notice that if $x, y$ are integers, then by parity analysis we know
$$
x^{2}+y^{2} \equiv 0,1,2(\bmod 4) \text {. }
$$

If $n \in S$, then from the above, $n \equiv 1(\bmod 4)$. Thus, we can set
$$
\begin{array}{l}
n-1=a^{2}+b^{2}, a \geqslant b, \\
n=c^{2}+d^{2}, c>d(c, d \text { cannot be equal }), \\
n+1=e^{2}+f^{2}, e \geqslant f,
\end{array}
$$

where $a, b, c, d, e, f$ are all positive integers.
Then $n^{2}+1=n^{2}+1^{2}, n^{2}=\left(c^{2}+d^{2}\right)^{2}=\left(c^{2}-d^{2}\right)^{2}+(2 c d)^{2}$,
$$
n^{2}-1=\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)\left(e^{2}+f^{2}\right)=(a e-b f)^{2}+(a f+b e)^{2} \text {. }
$$

Assume $b=a$, and $f=e$, then $n-1=2 a^{2}, n+1=2 e^{2}$, subtracting the two equations gives $e^{2}-a^{2}=1$, then $e-a \geqslant 1$, and $1=e^{2}-a^{2}=(e+a)(e-a)>1$, a contradiction!
Therefore, $b=a, f=e$ cannot both hold. So $a e-b f>0$, thus $n^{2} \in S$.
informal_statement:
Example 14 (2006 Western China Mathematical Olympiad) Let $S=\{n \mid n-1, n, n+1$ can all be expressed as the sum of two positive integers squared $\}$. Prove: if $n \in S$, then $n^{2} \in S$.

---

The translation maintains the original text's line breaks and format as requested.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 14 (2006 Western China Mathematical Olympiad) Let $S=\{n \mid n-1, n, n+1$ can all be expressed as the sum of two positive integers squared $\}$. Prove: if $n \in S$, then $n^{2} \in S$.

---

The translation maintains the original text's line breaks and format as requested. -/
theorem number_theory_295153 {S : Set ℕ} (hS : ∀ n ∈ S, ∃ m p q r s t : ℕ,
    m > 0 ∧ p > 0 ∧ q > 0 ∧ r > 0 ∧ s > 0 ∧ t > 0 ∧
    n - 1 = m^2 + p^2 ∧ n = q^2 + r^2 ∧ n + 1 = s^2 + t^2) :
    ∀ n ∈ S, n^2 ∈ S := by

soln_description:
【Analysis】That is, $10 \leq n \leq 100$, when $\mathrm{n}$ is a three-digit number, $\mathrm{n}$ is 100, which meets the requirement. When $\mathrm{n}$ is a two-digit number, let's assume $n=\overline{a b}=10 a+b$, at this time $10 a+b$ is a multiple of $a+b$, so $a+b|10 a+b \Rightarrow a+b| 9 a$
One, $a+b=a$ that is $b=0$, then $a \mid 9 a$, at this time $a$ can take 1 to 9, a total of 9 kinds
When $b \neq 0$, since $a+b>a$, and $a+b \mid 9 a$, so at this time $a+b$ must be a multiple of 3
Two, $a+b=3$, $3 \mid 9 a$, because $b \neq 0$, so there are $12, 21$, 2 kinds
Three, $a+b=6$, $6 \mid 9 a$, so $a$ should be even, because $b \neq 0$, so there are $24, 42$, 2 kinds
Four, $a+b=9$, $9 \mid 9 a$, because $b \neq 0$, so there are $18, 27, \cdots \cdots, 81$, 8 kinds
Five, $a+b=12$, $12 \mid 9 a$, so $a$ should be a multiple of 4, because $b \neq 0$, so there are $48, 84$, 2 kinds
Six, $a+b=15$, $15 \mid 9 a$, so $a$ should be a multiple of 5, there is no number that meets the condition
Seven, $a+b=18$, $18 \mid 9 a$, so $a$ should be even, there is no number that meets the condition
In summary, there are $1+9+2+2+8+2=24$ numbers
informal_statement: 19. $\mathrm{n}$ is a positive integer no greater than 100 and no less than 10, and $\mathrm{n}$ is a multiple of the sum of its digits, such $\mathrm{n}$ has ( ) numbers.
informal_proof:
We are asked to find the number of natural numbers $n$ such that $10 \leq n \leq 100$ and $n$ is divisible by the sum of its decimal digits. Let $S$ be the set of such numbers. We need to determine the cardinality of $S$.

The conditions can be formally stated as:
$S = \{ n \in \mathbb{N} \mid n \leq 100 \land n \geq 10 \land n \pmod{\text{sum of digits of } n} = 0 \}$

The proof establishes that this set $S$ is equivalent to a specific finite set derived from the conditions. This finite set consists of all natural numbers $n$ from 10 up to 100, filtered by the property that $n$ modulo the sum of its digits is zero.

The cardinality of this precisely defined finite set is then computed. This computation yields the result that there are exactly 24 such numbers.

For completeness, one can verify this by checking each number in the range:
- For $n=100$: Sum of digits is $1+0+0=1$. $100 \pmod 1 = 0$. So, 100 is counted.
- For $n$ in the range $[10, 99]$: Let $n = 10a + b$, where $a \in \{1, \dots, 9\}$ and $b \in \{0, \dots, 9\}$. The condition is $a+b \mid 10a+b$. This is equivalent to $a+b \mid 9a$.
  - If $b=0$: $n=10a$. Sum of digits is $a$. $a \mid 10a$, which is always true. This gives 9 numbers: 10, 20, ..., 90.
  - If $b \neq 0$: Analysis of $a+b \mid 9a$ yields:
    - $a+b=3$: 12, 21 (2 numbers)
    - $a+b=6$: 24, 42 (2 numbers)
    - $a+b=9$: 18, 27, 36, 45, 54, 63, 72, 81 (8 numbers)
    - $a+b=12$: 48, 84 (2 numbers)
    - Other possible values for $a+b$ (e.g., 15, 18) do not yield valid solutions.
  The total count for two-digit numbers is $9 + 2 + 2 + 8 + 2 = 23$.

Adding the number 100, the total count is $23 + 1 = 24$.
The cardinality of the set $S$ is 24.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 19. $\mathrm{n}$ is a positive integer no greater than 100 and no less than 10, and $\mathrm{n}$ is a multiple of the sum of its digits, such $\mathrm{n}$ has ( ) numbers. -/
theorem number_theory_149309 :
    Set.ncard {n : ℕ | n ≤ 100 ∧ n ≥ 10 ∧ n % (Nat.digits 10 n).sum = 0} = 24 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_149309 :
    Set.ncard {n : ℕ | n ≤ 100 ∧ n ≥ 10 ∧ n % (Nat.digits 10 n).sum = 0} = 24 := by
  have h1 : {n : ℕ | n ≤ 100 ∧ n ≥ 10 ∧ n % (Nat.digits 10 n).sum = 0} = Finset.filter (λ n => n ≥ 10 ∧ n % (Nat.digits 10 n).sum = 0) (Finset.Iic 100) := by
    ext n
    simp
    <;> omega
  rw [h1]
  rw [Set.ncard_coe_Finset]
  native_decide

informal_statement: Show that there exists a constant $a > 1$ such that, for any positive integers $m$ and $n$, $\frac{m}{n} < \sqrt7$ implies that $$7-\frac{m^2}{n^2} \ge \frac{a}{n^2} .$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Show that there exists a constant $a > 1$ such that, for any positive integers $m$ and $n$, $\frac{m}{n} < \sqrt7$ implies that $$7-\frac{m^2}{n^2} \ge \frac{a}{n^2} .$$ -/
theorem inequalities_82964 :
    ∃ a : ℝ, a > 1 ∧ ∀ m n : ℕ, 0 < m → 0 < n → m / n < sqrt 7 → 7 - m ^ 2 / n ^ 2 ≥ a / n ^ 2 := by

informal_statement:
Let $z_1$, $z_2$, $z_3$, $\dots$, $z_{12}$ be the 12 zeroes of the polynomial $z^{12} - 2^{36}$. For each $j$, let $w_j$ be one of $z_j$ or $iz_j$.  Find the maximum possible value of the real part of
\[\sum_{j = 1}^{12} w_j.\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real Polynomial Complex

/- Let $z_1$, $z_2$, $z_3$, $\dots$, $z_{12}$ be the 12 zeroes of the polynomial $z^{12} - 2^{36}$. For each $j$, let $w_j$ be one of $z_j$ or $iz_j$.  Find the maximum possible value of the real part of
\[\sum_{j = 1}^{12} w_j.\] -/
theorem calculus_16769 (z : ℕ → ℂ) (hz : ∀ n ∈ Icc 1 12, z n ^ 12 - 2 ^ 36 = 0)
    (w : ℕ → ℂ) (hw : ∀ j ∈ Icc 1 12, w j = z j ∨ w j = I * z j) :
    IsGreatest {x | ∃ t : Fin 12 → ℂ, (∀ i, t i = z i ∨ t i = I * z i) ∧ x = ∑ i, (t i).re} (16 + 16 * √3) := by

soln_description: 1. Since $a \geqslant 3$, it follows that $a-1$ has a prime factor $p$. By Fermat's Little Theorem, we know that $a^{p} \equiv a \equiv 1(\bmod p)$. Using induction, it is easy to prove that $n=p^{k}(k=1,2, \cdots)$ all meet the requirements.
informal_statement: 1 Prove that for any integer $a \geqslant 3$, there are infinitely many positive integers $n$ such that $a^{n}-1$ is divisible by $n$. (Please compare Example 2 of Unit 8.)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1 Prove that for any integer $a \geqslant 3$, there are infinitely many positive integers $n$ such that $a^{n}-1$ is divisible by $n$. (Please compare Example 2 of Unit 8.) -/
theorem number_theory_8011
(a : ℕ)
(ha : 3 ≤ a)
: { n : ℕ | 0 < n ∧ n ∣ a ^ n - 1 }.Infinite := by

soln_description:
Taking $x=\frac{1}{2}$ in (2), we get $f\left(\frac{1}{6}\right)=\frac{1}{2} f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{1}{4}$;
Taking $x=\frac{1}{3}$ in (2), we get $f\left(\frac{1}{9}\right)=\frac{1}{2} f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)=\frac{1}{4}$.
Since the function is non-decreasing, $\frac{1}{9}<\frac{1}{8}<\frac{1}{6}$, hence $f\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)=\frac{1}{4}$, so
$$
f\left(\frac{5}{12}\right)+f\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{3}{4} .
$$
informal_statement: 10 A function $f(x)$ has a domain $D$. If for any $x_{1}, x_{2} \in D$, when $x_{1}<x_{2}$, we have $f\left(x_{1}\right) \leqslant f\left(x_{2}\right)$, then the function $f(x)$ is called non-decreasing on $D$. Suppose the function $f(x)$ is non-decreasing on $[0,1]$ and satisfies the following three conditions: (1) $f(0)=0$; (2) $f\left(\frac{x}{3}\right)=\frac{1}{2} f(x)$; (3) $f(1-x)=1-f(x)$. Then $f\left(\frac{5}{12}\right)+f\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)=$ $\qquad$
informal_proof:
We are given a function $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ that is non-decreasing on the interval $[0, 1]$. It also satisfies the following properties:
1.  $f(0) = 0$.
2.  $f(x/3) = \frac{1}{2} f(x)$ for all $x \in [0, 1]$.
3.  $f(1-x) = 1 - f(x)$ for all $x \in [0, 1]$.

Our goal is to prove that $f(5/12) + f(1/8) = 3/4$.

First, let's determine the value of $f(1)$. Using property (3) with $x=0$:
$f(1 - 0) = 1 - f(0)$
$f(1) = 1 - 0$ (since $f(0)=0$)
$f(1) = 1$.

Next, let's find the value of $f(1/3)$. Using property (2) with $x=1$:
$f(1/3) = f(1/3) = \frac{1}{2} f(1)$
$f(1/3) = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 1$ (since $f(1)=1$)
$f(1/3) = \frac{1}{2}$.

Now, let's find the value of $f(2/3)$. Using property (3) with $x=1/3$:
$f(1 - 1/3) = 1 - f(1/3)$
$f(2/3) = 1 - \frac{1}{2}$ (since $f(1/3)=1/2$)
$f(2/3) = \frac{1}{2}$.

We need to find $f(5/12)$. Since the function $f$ is non-decreasing on $[0, 1]$ and we know $f(1/3) = 1/2$ and $f(2/3) = 1/2$, we can establish bounds for $f(5/12)$.
We observe that $1/3 \leq 5/12 \leq 2/3$.
Specifically, $1/3 = 4/12$, so $4/12 \leq 5/12$.
And $5/12 \leq 2/3$, because $5/12 \leq 8/12$.
Since $f$ is non-decreasing, we have:
$f(1/3) \leq f(5/12) \leq f(2/3)$
$\frac{1}{2} \leq f(5/12) \leq \frac{1}{2}$.
This implies that $f(5/12) = \frac{1}{2}$.

Next, we need to find $f(1/8)$. To do this, we first find $f(3/8)$.
Again, using the non-decreasing property and the values we've found:
We have $1/3 \leq 3/8 \leq 2/3$.
To verify this: $1/3 = 8/24$ and $3/8 = 9/24$, so $8/24 \leq 9/24$.
Also, $3/8 = 9/24$ and $2/3 = 16/24$, so $9/24 \leq 16/24$.
Since $f$ is non-decreasing:
$f(1/3) \leq f(3/8) \leq f(2/3)$
$\frac{1}{2} \leq f(3/8) \leq \frac{1}{2}$.
This implies that $f(3/8) = \frac{1}{2}$.

Now we can find $f(1/8)$ using property (2) with $x=3/8$:
$f((3/8)/3) = \frac{1}{2} f(3/8)$
$f(1/8) = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2}$ (since $f(3/8)=1/2$)
$f(1/8) = \frac{1}{4}$.

Finally, we can compute the sum $f(5/12) + f(1/8)$:
$f(5/12) + f(1/8) = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{4} = \frac{2}{4} + \frac{1}{4} = \frac{3}{4}$.

Thus, we have shown that $f(5/12) + f(1/8) = 3/4$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10 A function $f(x)$ has a domain $D$. If for any $x_{1}, x_{2} \in D$, when $x_{1}<x_{2}$, we have $f\left(x_{1}\right) \leqslant f\left(x_{2}\right)$, then the function $f(x)$ is called non-decreasing on $D$. Suppose the function $f(x)$ is non-decreasing on $[0,1]$ and satisfies the following three conditions: (1) $f(0)=0$; (2) $f\left(\frac{x}{3}\right)=\frac{1}{2} f(x)$; (3) $f(1-x)=1-f(x)$. Then $f\left(\frac{5}{12}\right)+f\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)=$ $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_241068 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ x ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, ∀ y ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, x < y → f x ≤ f y)
    (h0 : f 0 = 0) (h1 : ∀ x ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, f (x / 3) = (1 / 2) * f x) (h2 : ∀ x ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, f (1 - x) = 1 - f x) :
    f (5 / 12) + f (1 / 8) = 3 / 4 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_241068 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ x ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, ∀ y ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, x < y → f x ≤ f y)
    (h0 : f 0 = 0) (h1 : ∀ x ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, f (x / 3) = (1 / 2) * f x) (h2 : ∀ x ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, f (1 - x) = 1 - f x) :
    f (5 / 12) + f (1 / 8) = 3 / 4 := by
  have f1 : f 1 = 1 := by
    have h20 := h2 0 (by norm_num)
    norm_num at h20
    linarith [h0]
  have f1_3 : f (1 / 3) = 1 / 2 := by
    specialize h1 1 (by norm_num)
    norm_num at h1 ⊢
    linarith [f1]
  have f2_3 : f (2 / 3) = 1 / 2 := by
    specialize h2 (1 / 3) (by norm_num)
    norm_num at h2 ⊢
    linarith [f1_3]
  have f5_12 : f (5 / 12) = 1 / 2 := by
    have h5 : f (1 / 3) ≤ f (5 / 12) := by
      apply hf
      all_goals norm_num
    have h5' : f (5 / 12) ≤ f (2 / 3) := by
      apply hf
      all_goals norm_num
    linarith [f1_3, f2_3, h5, h5']
  have f3_8 : f (3 / 8) = 1 / 2 := by
    have h15 : f (1 / 3) ≤ f (3 / 8) := by
      apply hf
      all_goals norm_num
    have h15' : f (3 / 8) ≤ f (2 / 3) := by
      apply hf
      all_goals norm_num
    linarith [f1_3, f2_3, h15, h15']
  have h15 : f (1 / 8) = (1 / 2) * f (3 / 8) := by
    specialize h1 (3 / 8) (by norm_num)
    norm_num at h1 ⊢
    linarith [h1]
  have f1_8 : f (1 / 8) = 1 / 4 := by
    rw [h15]
    linarith [f3_8]
  linarith [f5_12, f1_8]

informal_statement:
Find all functions $f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}$ such that for all $x, y \in \mathbb{N}$, the following equation holds:
$$(xf(y) + yf(x))^{x+y} = f(x)f(y)(x+y)^{x+y}.$$
informal_proof:
We aim to characterize all functions $f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}$ such that for every pair of natural numbers $x$ and $y$, the following equation holds:
$$(xf(y) + yf(x))^{x+y} = f(x)f(y)(x+y)^{x+y}.$$
We will show that this condition is satisfied if and only if $f(x) = 1$ for all $x \in \mathbb{N}$.

First, let us assume that the given equation holds for all $x, y \in \mathbb{N}$. We will prove by induction that $f(x) = 1$ for all $x \in \mathbb{N}$.

We begin by establishing the values of $f(0)$ and $f(1)$.
Consider the case when $x=0$ and $y=0$. Substituting these values into the equation, we get:
$$(0 \cdot f(0) + 0 \cdot f(0))^{0+0} = f(0)f(0)(0+0)^{0+0}.$$
This simplifies to $0^0 = f(0)^2 \cdot 0^0$. By convention, $0^0 = 1$. Thus, we have $1 = f(0)^2 \cdot 1$, which implies $f(0)^2 = 1$. Since $f$ maps to $\mathbb{N}$, $f(0)$ must be a non-negative integer. The only non-negative integer whose square is $1$ is $1$. Therefore, $f(0)=1$.

Now, consider the case when $x=1$ and $y=0$. Substituting these values and using $f(0)=1$:
$$(1 \cdot f(0) + 0 \cdot f(1))^{1+0} = f(1)f(0)(1+0)^{1+0}.$$
This simplifies to $(1 \cdot 1 + 0)^{1} = f(1) \cdot 1 \cdot (1)^{1}$, which is $1^1 = f(1) \cdot 1$. Thus, $1 = f(1)$.

We now proceed with induction to show that $f(x) = 1$ for all $x \in \mathbb{N}$. We have already shown the base cases $f(0)=1$ and $f(1)=1$.
Assume for some $x \in \mathbb{N}$ that $f(k)=1$ for all $k \leq x$. We want to show that $f(x+1)=1$.
We use the original equation by setting $y=0$ and replacing $x$ with $x+1$. The equation becomes:
$$((x+1)f(0) + 0 \cdot f(x+1))^{(x+1)+0} = f(x+1)f(0)(x+1+0)^{(x+1)+0}.$$
Using our established result $f(0)=1$, this simplifies to:
$$((x+1) \cdot 1 + 0)^{x+1} = f(x+1) \cdot 1 \cdot (x+1)^{x+1}.$$
This yields $(x+1)^{x+1} = f(x+1)(x+1)^{x+1}$.
Since $x \in \mathbb{N}$, $x+1$ is at least $1$, so $(x+1)^{x+1}$ is a positive integer. We can divide both sides of the equation by $(x+1)^{x+1}$ to get $1 = f(x+1)$.
By the principle of mathematical induction, $f(x)=1$ for all $x \in \mathbb{N}$.

Conversely, assume that $f(x)=1$ for all $x \in \mathbb{N}$. We must verify that the given equation holds for all $x, y \in \mathbb{N}$.
Substitute $f(x)=1$ and $f(y)=1$ into the left-hand side of the equation:
$$(x \cdot f(y) + y \cdot f(x))^{x+y} = (x \cdot 1 + y \cdot 1)^{x+y} = (x+y)^{x+y}.$$
Now, substitute $f(x)=1$ and $f(y)=1$ into the right-hand side of the equation:
$$f(x)f(y)(x+y)^{x+y} = 1 \cdot 1 \cdot (x+y)^{x+y} = (x+y)^{x+y}.$$
